They don't know if Marcus is at peace now. They don't know if Marcus was ever really Marcus at all. Their father got passed over for the promotion again. Their mother's funding application was rejected. Nothing has changed in the visible world. The protagonist still has to take their exams, still has to sit through tedious lessons, still has to navigate their life. But something has shifted, some weight has lifted, and they can't quite identify what it is. The final image: the protagonist standing at their bedroom window, early morning, watching the fog over the sea. The window has not fogged in weeks. There is no message. They don't know what to feel about any of it, and they don't think they will ever fully know. They turn away, and they go about their day, and that's the whole story. *Word count target: ~1000 words*
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# The Protagonist (Unnamed) ## Background, Personality, and Idiosyncrasies The protagonist is fifteen years old, the child of middle-class parents who moved to Bleakford before they were born seeking a "better quality of life" that neither parent can now remember defining. They are the product of a school that selects by ability and a family that selected them for that school through tuition they can barely afford—a scholarship kid in a school full of people whose parents pay, which sounds like a movie cliché until you actually live it and discover that movie clichés exist because they're true. Their defining trait is a commitment to rationality that borders on the pathological. They have read Skeptical Inquirer articles for fun. They can articulate exactly why homeopathy is nonsense and why ghosts probably don't exist, and they've constructed an elaborate worldview in which everything has a rational explanation and anything that doesn't simply hasn't been explained yet. This worldview is, of course, a coping mechanism—something they constructed to manage a childhood in which their parents were often distracted and the world felt unreliable. But they don't think of it that way. They think of it as thinking clearly. Their idiosyncrasies are small and specific. They have a particular way of organizing their desk—pens in the left mug, notebooks in a specific stack, highlighters arranged by color even though they never use three of the four colors. They count things without meaning to: the steps from their bedroom to the bathroom, the number of times their father sighs during dinner, the seconds between text notifications. They hate the sound of other people eating but have never told anyone this because it seems too weird to mention. They have a recurring dream about a door they can't find, which they've had since they were eight and which they've interpreted to mean nothing because that's what they do with everything. Their flaw is that their skepticism makes them dismissive of information that doesn't fit their framework. When Priya immediately believes in the blood emojis, the protagonist writes off her belief as credulity rather than considering that Priya might be onto something. When Mr. Hassan initially refuses to talk, the protagonist assumes he's just an old man who doesn't want to be bothered, not that he might be carrying decades of guilt. They are, in short, intelligent in ways that blind them, and they'll have to learn that intelligence is knowing when to doubt your doubts. ## Physicality They are neither tall nor short, neither athletic nor sedentary, the kind of person who could pass through a crowd without being noticed and would consider this a feature rather than a bug. They have their mother's sharp chin and their father's tendency to hunch slightly when reading, which they deny doing despite photographic evidence. Their hair does a thing in humidity that they fight daily and always lose. They wear clothes that are clean and presentable but not interesting—plain shirts, comfortable jeans, shoes they've had for two years and will have for two more. They carry themselves with an awareness of being watched, even when they're not. They have a habit of scanning rooms when they enter, taking in exits and available seats, a behavior they've never consciously developed but that serves them now as the texts escalate. Their resting expression is neutral-to-skeptical, which teachers have interpreted as "too serious" and which they have interpreted as "accurate assessment of most situations." When they're nervous, they tap their fingers against their thigh in a rhythm they've never consciously noticed but that their mother has pointed out, which made them self-conscious about it, which made it worse. ## Motives, Allegiances, and Relationships The protagonist's primary motive is to be left alone to live their life. They did not ask for blood emojis. They do not want to be involved in thirty-year-old crimes. They would like to pass their exams, get decent grades, and emerge from adolescence relatively intact. Everything in this story is an unwelcome intrusion into that plan. Their allegiances are few but deep. They are loyal to Priya even when her enthusiasm exhausts them. They love their parents even when their parents' preoccupations make them feel invisible. They have a complicated relationship with their own skepticism, trusting it even as it potentially lets them down. Their relationship with Priya is the closest thing they have to a defined friendship—they've been friends since primary school, when Priya defended them from a kid who was taking their lunch money and they've been attached since. The relationship is characterized by Priya's warmth and the protagonist's grudging reciprocation. They don't say "I love you" to each other. They say things like "You're being ridiculous" in a tone that means something else. Their relationship with their parents is loving but weirdly formal. They don't discuss feelings at the dinner table. They discuss the news, the weather, their father's work frustrations, their mother's community center. The protagonist knows, in an abstract way, that their parents love them. They also know that their parents have their own struggles and that the protagonist is expected to manage independently, which they do, even when managing is hard. ## Voice Experiments *Internal monologue, waking to find HELP on the window:* "Right. Okay. So either someone got into my room and wrote on my window—which would mean they climbed two stories and somehow didn't set off the motion sensor lights or make any noise, and also they were kind enough to write the word 'help' instead of, I don't know, murdering me—or something else happened. Something I don't have an explanation for. Which is fine. I don't have to have an explanation for everything. People go their whole lives without explanations for things. They're called religious people, mostly, or conspiracy theorists. I'm neither. I'm just someone who had a weird night and will probably never figure out what happened and will have to live with that, which is fine, it's absolutely fine, I'm completely not lying awake for the next four hours." *Responding to Priya's enthusiasm:* "Priya, I need you to understand something. I am not interested in going to the pier at midnight to 'feel the presence.' I am not interested in conducting a seance. I am not interested in any of this, period. I woke up last night to find someone—or something, because you're going to say 'or something'—had written on my window. This is not a fun adventure. This is potentially a break-in that didn't involve anything being stolen, which means either it wasn't a break-in or the person who broke in has very specific tastes in what they take, which is apparently messages on windows. This is weird and I don't like it and I would like to stop talking about it now." --- # Priya Desai ## Background, Personality, and Idiosyncrasies Priya is sixteen, a year older than the protagonist, which she uses to claim maturity she doesn't always possess. Her parents run the only Indian restaurant in Bleakford, a establishment that has survived three recessions and the general decline of the town's tourist economy through sheer stubbornness and the fact that their tikka masala is genuinely excellent. She has grown up in the back of this restaurant, doing homework in the corner booth, waiting tables on weekends, absorbing the rhythms of small business ownership and the particular exhaustion of immigrants who built a life in a place that never quite accepted them. Her personality is warm and expansive in contrast to the protagonist's reserved nature. She believes in things—ghosts, karma, the fundamental goodness of most people, the idea that everything happens for a reason—and she holds these beliefs not naively but as a deliberate choice. She has seen the worst of what small towns can offer to families that don't fit, and she has decided that belief in something better is an act of resistance. This doesn't always serve her well. She can be credulous. She can ignore warning signs because she wants to believe. But it also makes her brave in ways the protagonist isn't. Her idiosyncrasies include a collection of crystals that she keeps on her windowsill for no reason she can explain other than that they were her grandmother's. She has a habit of touching her earrings when she's nervous, a gesture she's done since childhood. She sings under her breath without realizing she's doing it, usually songs from Bollywood films that her mother played when she was small. She is genuinely, unironically kind to Jade Hart despite Jade's nastiness, because she believes everyone is going through something, which the protagonist finds irritating. Her flaw is that her desire to believe sometimes overrides her judgment. She wants the blood emojis to be supernatural so badly that she might miss the mundane explanation—or might miss the fact that the mundane explanation isn't the whole story either. She wants to help so much that she might push the protagonist into something they're not ready for. Her heart is in the right place, but her instincts need checking. ## Physicality Priya is taller than the protagonist by several inches, a fact she uses when she wants to be physically reassuring—putting an arm around their shoulder, standing slightly in front of them when she's worried. She has her mother's elaborate black hair, which she wears in different styles depending on her mood, and her father's habit of gesturing broadly when she talks. She dresses in colors that the protagonist has never dared to wear—deep reds, mustard yellows, patterns that make her visible in a crowd. She moves through the world like someone who expects to be noticed, which is sometimes true and sometimes a performance she puts on because expecting not to be noticed feels worse. Her face is expressive in ways the protagonist's isn't. Where the protagonist's features settle into skeptical neutrality, Priya's face registers everything—joy, concern, suspicion, hope. She has a scar on her left knee from a bicycle accident when she was nine, which she shows to anyone who asks because she thinks it makes her look interesting. She wears a thin gold chain that belonged to her grandmother, and she touches it when she's thinking about family things. ## Motives, Allegiances, and Relationships Priya's primary motive is to protect her friend while also satisfying her own curiosity. She has always felt that Bleakford was haunted by something, and the blood emojis feel like confirmation of what she suspected. She wants to help the protagonist, but she also wants to be right. This creates tension—she might prioritize her desire to be proven right over what the protagonist actually needs. Her allegiances are to the protagonist, to her family, and to a general sense of justice that she carries without being able to articulate where it came from. She believes in doing the right thing but isn't always sure what the right thing is. Her relationship with the protagonist is the central friendship of the story. She has watched them build walls their whole life and has learned to respect those walls while occasionally trying to climb over them. She knows the protagonist is hiding things from her even before the blood emojis start—she can feel the distance in the way they answer questions, the way they change the subject. She loves them anyway, even when they're impossible. ## Voice Experiments *Reacting to the blood emojis:* "Oh, that's not good. That's not good at all. Okay, okay, don't freak out—I'm not saying freak out, I'm saying this is serious. This is like, this is exactly the kind of thing I've always thought was happening in this town. Remember when that kid went missing in 2019? Everyone said he ran away but I always thought—sorry, sorry, I'm not helping. I'm doing the thing where I make it about my theories. What do you want to do? Do you want to go to the pier? I will go to the pie with you. I will go anywhere you want. We can figure this out together. I'm not going anywhere." *Trying to be practical:* "Have you eaten? When's the last time you ate something that wasn't a biscuit? I'm serious, you can't solve ghost mysteries on an empty stomach. There's this thing where your brain needs glucose to, I don't know, do brain things. Come on, we're going to the Budget Express. You're getting a sandwich. I'm getting you a sandwich. This is non-negotiable. Ghosts can wait ten minutes for you to consume some carbohydrates." --- # The Father ## Background, Personality, and Idiosyncrasies The father is forty-seven, a project manager for a civil engineering firm that mainly does work for local councils, a job he has held for twelve years and that has gradually transformed him from someone who used to laugh easily into someone who sighs frequently and checks his email at odd hours. He grew up in a mining village in Yorkshire, the first in his family to go to university, and he carries the particular burden of someone who escaped a certain life and is now perpetually afraid of sliding back into it. This fear manifests as overwork and overconcern with stability—keeping the job, keeping the house, keeping his daughter in a school that represents everything he fought to achieve. His personality is kind but distracted. He loves his daughter but doesn't know how to talk to her in the way she needs—doesn't know how to ask what's wrong without making it feel like an interrogation, doesn't know how to offer comfort without it feeling forced. He has been told, by his wife, that he "lives in his head too much," and he knows this is true but doesn't know how to change it. He is the kind of person who thinks he's being present when he's actually thinking about a deadline. His idiosyncrasies include a tendency to hum the theme tune to programs he watched as a child—specifically, he hums the Newsroom theme while making coffee, which his daughter has never pointed out because she doesn't want to have a conversation about it. He has a specific way of slicing bread that his wife makes fun of but that he maintains is the correct way. He keeps a photo of his father in his desk drawer, a man who died when he was nineteen, and he looks at it when he's stressed without being able to explain why. His flaw is that he prioritizes stability over honesty, which means he doesn't tell his family when things are wrong at work—he just gets quieter, more distant, more focused on the wrong things. His daughter learns to read his moods through his silences, which he never realizes he's teaching her to do. ## Physicality He is going grey at the temples in a way that his daughter has noticed but he hasn't, a detail she finds depressing in a way she can't explain. He is slightly overweight, carrying the "dad bod" of a man who used to be athletic and stopped being so without noticing. He wears shirts with the sleeves rolled up even in winter because he runs warm, which his wife teases him about. He has a way of standing with his hands behind his back that makes him look like he's waiting for something, a habit from years of waiting in construction sites for permits and approvals. His face is tired in a way that seems permanent. When he smiles, which is less often than he used to, it transforms him—his daughter always notices and always feels a small pang when she realizes how rarely he does it anymore. He walks with a slight limp from a football injury in his twenties that never healed quite right, which he blames on the weather when anyone asks. ## Motives, Allegiances, and Relationships His primary motive is to provide stability for his family, a goal he pursues through work and routine even when those things are failing him. He has been passed over for promotion twice in the last year and hasn't told his wife, convinced that if he works harder, things will turn around. This secret is slowly poisoning him, but he doesn't know how to stop. His allegiances are to his wife, his daughter, and a concept of family that he inherited from his own upbringing—the idea that you protect your family by shielding them from your problems, even when shielding them means lying. His relationship with his daughter is loving but increasingly distant. They used to talk when she was younger—about school, about his work, about nothing in particular. Now they have dinner together and discuss the news and he can feel her pulling away and doesn't know how to stop it. He notices that she's been acting strange lately, seems distracted, seems tired, but he assumes it's exam stress because that's easier than asking what's actually wrong. He's not sure he wants to know. ## Voice Experiments *At dinner, trying to connect:* "So, any good lessons today? Anything interesting happen? I remember when I was your age, we had this history teacher, Mr.—what was his name, Sandra, you'll know this—anyway, he used to make us memorize dates but he'd tell us stories about what people were actually like, you know, not just the facts. Made it feel real. Any teachers like that? No? Well, that's a shame. The good ones make you care about stuff you didn't think you'd care about. Anyway. More potatoes?" *Alone, reading a rejection email:* "Right. Right. Okay. That's—I mean, I knew it was a long shot. Obviously. They were always going to promote from within, that's what they said, and Roberts has been there longer, it's fine, it's completely fine. I'll just—I'll keep doing what I'm doing. Work harder. Prove myself. Next time. There's always next time. That's what you do. You keep going. You don't stop. You can't stop." --- # The Mother ## Background, Personality, and Idiosyncrasies The mother is forty-five, a former primary school teacher who left the profession when her daughter started secondary school, telling everyone she wanted "more time" but actually unable to face another decade of underpaid, underappreciated labor in a system that didn't value her. She now volunteers at the community center, running an after-school program for younger children, a job that fulfills her need to be useful while not requiring her to make hard decisions about her own career. She is, underneath the exhaustion, the more emotionally attuned parent—the one who notices when her daughter is quiet, who asks questions that cut a little too close, who makes the protagonist uncomfortable in ways the father doesn't. Her personality is warm but anxious. She worries about things that haven't happened yet, constructs worst-case scenarios, lies awake at night thinking about the future. This anxiety is invisible to her family most of the time—she manages it through busyness, through volunteering, through always having something to do. But it leaks out in small ways: the way she double-checks doors and windows, the way she asks "are you sure?" when the protagonist says they're fine. Her idiosyncrasies include a collection of teapots—seven of them, each from a different era and each with a different personality as far as she's concerned. She talks to plants, which she's done since before the protagonist was born, and she's convinced they respond to her voice. She has a specific way of making tea that takes seven minutes exactly and that she will not compromise on, even when guests are waiting. She quotes poetry at random moments, usually without indicating she's doing it, which her husband finds endearing and her daughter finds mortifying. Her flaw is that she avoids conflict in ways that sometimes make things worse. She knows her husband is struggling at work but doesn't push him to talk about it because she hates confrontation. She knows her daughter is hiding something but doesn't ask because she's afraid of what the answer might be. Her love is real but sometimes enabling, sometimes allowing problems to fester rather than addressing them. ## Physicality She is shorter than her daughter will be, a fact she acknowledges with good humor, and she has the kind of face that looks younger than her age until she's tired, at which point every year shows. She wears her hair in a practical bob that she cuts herself, and she has a habit of tucking it behind her ears when she's listening to someone. She dresses in layers—cardigans over shirts, scarves even in summer—partly because she runs cold and partly because she likes the feeling of being wrapped up. She has kind eyes, which everyone says, and she hates it when people say it because it makes her feel like her identity is limited to being nice. She moves quickly through her house, always busy, always doing three things at once, never sitting still for long. When she does sit still, she reads—poetry collections, mostly, or novels in languages she's trying to maintain, French and German she learned at school and never quite let go of. ## Motives, Allegiances, and Relationships Her primary motive is to keep her family together and functional, a goal she pursues through emotional labor that goes mostly unnoticed. She wants her husband to be happy and doesn't know how to help him. She wants her daughter to trust her and doesn't know how to build that trust. She wants her own life to have meaning beyond the volunteer work and the teapots and the poetry quotes, but she's not sure what that would look like. Her allegiances are to her family first and to herself a distant second. She has put herself last for so long that she's not sure she remembers what first would feel like. Her relationship with her daughter is characterized by a desire for closeness that the daughter resists. She knows her daughter is growing away from her and that this is normal and healthy, but it still hurts. She notices things—the dark circles under her eyes, the way she jumps at notifications, the way she avoids certain topics—and she files them away to ask about later, a later that keeps not coming because she keeps not asking. ## Voice Experiments *At dinner, trying to draw out her daughter:* "You know, the strangest thing happened at the center today. One of the little ones, Amara, she drew me a picture—flowers, mostly, but there was this one part, she said it was the sea, but it looked like—I don't know, like fog, I suppose. And she said, 'This is where the sad people live.' And I thought, well, that's a strange thing for a five-year-old to say. Children notice everything, don't they? They see things we don't anymore. What do you think, love? Anything strange happening at school? Anything you want to talk about? No? Well, the door's always open. You know that." *Alone, after her husband goes to bed:* "Seven minutes. That's all it takes. Seven minutes and you have the perfect cup of tea. Harold never understands that—he wants it stronger, he wants it sooner, he doesn't realize that good things take time. Everything worth doing takes time. But he can't see that, he's so focused on the next deadline, the next promotion, the next thing that will make everything okay. I should talk to him. I should ask what's really going on. I will. Tomorrow. I'll ask tomorrow." --- # Jade Hart ## Background, Personality, and Idiosyncrasies Jade is fifteen, the daughter of a family that has lived in Bleakford for four generations and that owns most of the commercial property on the seafront—the pier, the amusement arcade, the hotel that's been closed for renovation since 2019. She has grown up in a house that feels more like a museum than a home, surrounded by antiques her mother polishes obsessively and ancestral portraits that watch her from every wall. She is the inheritor of a legacy she didn't choose and doesn't know how to escape. Her personality is cruel, but cruelty is rarely simple. She is cruel because she was raised to believe that status matters and that demonstrating status is survival. She is cruel because her parents are cold and this is the only warmth she knows how to generate. She is cruel because she is frightened—frightened of her father, frightened of the future, frightened of the secrets she can feel her family carrying and that no one will explain to her. Her idiosyncrasies include a tendency to click her tongue against her teeth when she's thinking, a gesture she picked up from her father and hates herself for. She carries a compact mirror that she checks obsessively, not because she cares about her appearance but because it gives her an excuse to avoid eye contact. She has a small collection of postcards from places she's never been—Barcelona, Tokyo, Reykjavik—that she keeps in her desk drawer and looks at when she needs to remember that the world is bigger than Bleakford. Her flaw is that she is cruel to others because she doesn't know how to be anything else. She has never been taught. She has never been shown an alternative. And beneath the cruelty, there is something that might be a person worth knowing, if anyone ever took the time to find out. ## Physicality Jade is pretty in an aggressive way—expensive clothes, careful hair, a face that has clearly been taught how to arrange itself for maximum effect. She carries herself like someone who expects to be obeyed, shoulders back, chin up, voice calibrated to cut. But there's something fragile underneath the performance. When she thinks no one is looking, her face settles into something flat and tired. When she collides with the protagonist in the corridor, for a moment before the cruelty kicks in, she looks almost frightened. She has her mother's nose and her father's eyes, a combination that makes her look older than she is. She bites her nails when she's alone, a habit she's had since childhood and one she's deeply ashamed of because it costs money to fix and her mother is always pointing it out. ## Motives, Allegiances, and Relationships Her primary motive is to survive her family without being destroyed by them. She knows, on some level, that her family's wealth is built on something wrong—she has seen her father's face when the pier is mentioned, has heard her mother speak in hushed tones about "old business." But she doesn't know how to confront this knowledge, so she pretends it doesn't exist. Her allegiances are complicated. She is loyal to her family because she has no choice. She is loyal to herself because she has nothing else. She is not loyal to anyone at school, not really—they're all either below her or, in the protagonist's case, a reminder of everything she's afraid to become. Her relationship with the protagonist is characterized by the protagonist's scholarship status, which Jade fixates on because it represents a world where worth is earned rather than inherited. She hates the protagonist for needing a scholarship, which is irrational but not uncommon. She also, somewhere beneath the hate, admires the protagonist's brains, though she'd rather die than admit it. ## Voice Experiments *After colliding in the corridor:* "Watch where you're going, scholarship. Not everyone can afford to float through life without paying attention. Some of us have actual things to do. Some of us have—actually, forget it. Forget I said anything. You're not worth it. You're really not worth it. Just get out of my way." *Alone, after hearing the news about her family:* "It's not true. None of it is true. They wouldn't—my father wouldn't—he wouldn't do that to someone. He wouldn't—okay. Okay. Maybe he would. Maybe he did. Maybe all those years of—" She stops. She looks at her hands. She doesn't finish the sentence because she doesn't know how to say what she's thinking. What she's thinking is: what does it mean to be someone whose family did that? What does it mean to be me? --- # Mrs. Okonkwo ## Background, Personality, and Idiosyncrasies Mrs. Okonkwo is sixty-three, the librarian of Bleakford's public library for twenty-one years, a position she took after her husband died and she needed something to fill the time. That something became her life—the library, the books, the quiet routine of ordering and cataloguing and shelving. She has read every book in the building, most of them twice, and she has opinions about all of them that she shares when asked and keeps to herself when not. Her personality is warm but careful. She has learned, in her years behind the desk, that people come to libraries for many reasons—some want help, some want to be left alone, some are looking for something they can't articulate. She is skilled at reading these needs and responding appropriately. She is also skilled at knowing when not to know things—some questions are better left unasked, some research paths better left untrod. Her idiosyncrasies include a habit of sniffing books before shelving them, a gesture from her childhood in Nigeria where books were precious and rare and deserved respect. She keeps a thermos of chamomile tea at her desk and refills it throughout the day. She knows the Dewey Decimal System by memory and will tell you, if asked, exactly where to find any book in the building and approximately how long it will take you to walk there. Her flaw is that she sometimes lets her caution override her compassion. She knows the protagonist is researching something sensitive—she remembers the Chen case, vaguely, the way you remember any tragedy that happened in a small town. She could help more than she does. But she's afraid of what might happen if she does. She's old enough to know that some questions, once asked, can't be unasked. ## Physicality Mrs. Okonkwo is a small woman with an air of quiet authority, the kind of person who can silence a room by walking into it without meaning to. She wears glasses on a chain around her neck and puts them on when she needs to read something closely. She has a way of looking at people over these glasses that makes them feel like they've been assessed and found wanting—not in a cruel way, just in a thorough way. Her hands are thin and capable, good at handling books without damaging spines. She moves slowly through the library, a figure of routine that patrons come to expect—the shelves creaking, the clock ticking, Mrs. Okonkwo humming something under her breath that might be a hymn or might be nothing at all. ## Motives, Allegiances, and Relationships Her primary motive is to maintain the library as a space of safety and knowledge, a goal she pursues through quiet stewardship and careful boundaries. She is not trying to stop the protagonist from researching, but she's not going to help them either. She has her own reasons for this reticence—reasons connected to her years in Bleakford and the things she's seen and chosen not to see. Her allegiances are to the truth, such as it is, and to the community she's served for two decades. She wants what's best for the protagonist, but she's not sure what that is, and she's not going to guess. Her relationship with the protagonist is briefly functional—she provides access to information and a warning that isn't quite a warning. She will not be a major character in the story, but she represents something: the weight of history, the silence that communities keep, the cost of looking away. ## Voice Experiments *Watching the protagonist research:* "The Chen case. I thought that was behind us. I thought all of that was behind us. You know, I remember when it happened—I'd only been here two years then. Such a young man. Such a tragedy. Or that's what they called it. A tragedy. That's what they call it when they don't want to call it what it really is. You be careful, won't you? Some questions are better left unasked. I'm not saying don't ask them. I'm just saying—be careful." *To herself, after the protagonist leaves:* "Thirty-seven years. I've been here twenty-one of them, but I remember the rest. I remember how quiet everything got after Marcus died. How everyone stopped talking about it. That's how it works in places like this. You stop talking and then you stop remembering and then it never happened at all. But it did happen. I remember. I always remembered." --- # Mr. Hassan ## Background, Personality, and Idiosyncrasies Mr. Hassan is seventy-four, a retired police officer who served thirty years in the Bleakford constabulary, the last fifteen of them as a detective sergeant before mandatory retirement forced him out. He was the young constable on the Marcus Chen case in 1987, the one who was told to close it and who, for reasons he's never fully understood himself, did what he was told. He has spent thirty-seven years living with this decision, and it has not been easy. His personality is shaped by guilt, though he'd never use that word. He thinks of it as responsibility, or duty, or simply the weight of a choice he made that he can't unmake. He is not a bitter man, but he is a tired one—the particular exhaustion of someone who has been carrying something for too long and has forgotten what it feels like not to carry it. His idiosyncrasies include a collection of model police cars, a hobby he took up after retirement that has filled his house with tiny vehicles he arranges and rearranges according to no pattern anyone else can discern. He talks to his cats—three of them, each named after a retired colleague—about his problems, because talking to people requires explaining things he doesn't want to explain. He has not had a proper conversation with another human being in months, possibly years, and he has stopped noticing. His flaw is that he froze when it mattered and has never forgiven himself for it. He knows, rationally, that he was young and frightened and following orders. But rationality has never made guilt go away. He has been waiting for someone to come along who might help him finally do something about what happened, and now that someone is here, he's not sure he's ready. ## Physicality Mr. Hassan is tall but bent, his spine curving forward from years of leaning over case files and interview tables. He has a white beard that he trims carelessly and eyes that look tired in a way that has nothing to do with sleep. He moves slowly through his cluttered house, stepping over cat toys and model cars, a figure of decline that is hard to reconcile with the man he used to be. He wears cardigans even in summer, because he feels the cold now in ways he didn't when he was young. He has a specific chair by the window where he sits for hours, watching the street, waiting for something he can't name. When he was younger, he used to stand in this exact spot and watch for his wife to come home from her night shifts. He still watches, even though she's been gone for six years. ## Motives, Allegiances, and Relationships His primary motive is to unburden himself before he dies, though he'd never put it that directly. He wants someone to know what he did—what they made him do—and to understand that he wasn't proud of it. He wants absolution but doesn't believe he deserves it. He wants justice for Marcus Chen but doesn't know if justice is still possible. His allegiances are complicated. He is still, in some sense, a police officer—he believes in the system, even though the system failed Marcus. He is also a man who failed a boy who needed help, and that failure has defined the rest of his life. His relationship with the protagonist is the pivot point of the story. He gives them the truth they've been seeking, but only because he's tired of carrying it alone. He doesn't know if he's doing the right thing. He doesn't know what will happen next. He only knows that he can't keep silent anymore. ## Voice Experiments *Opening the door to the protagonist:* "You again. I've been thinking about you. Thinking about whether I should talk to you or not. I don't even know your name. Do I know your name? It doesn't matter. Names don't matter. What matters is what you want from me. You want to know about Marcus Chen. You want to know what happened in 1987. I can tell you. I can tell you everything. But once I start, I can't stop. Do you understand that? Once you know, you can't unknow it. Are you sure you want to know?" *After telling the story:* "I was twenty-six years old. I was a constable. I was told to close the case and I closed it. That's what they called it—closing the case. As if you were shutting a door. As if it was simple. Marcus Chen was seventeen years old and he drowned and it wasn't an accident and everyone knew it and no one did anything. I did nothing. I was there and I did nothing and I've been doing nothing ever since. Every day I wake up and I think about it and every day I don't do anything. So if you're asking me to do something now—I don't know if I can. I don't know if I have anything left to give."

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter One The first text arrived at 12:03 AM, which I know because I was staring at my phone screen, willing myself to fall asleep and failing. My alarm was set for 6:15. I had been lying there for forty-seven minutes, not counting, though I was counting, I always count things without meaning to, and the number forty-seven had lodged itself in my brain like a splinter I couldn't dislodge. The notification appeared above my battery indicator: *Unknown Number*. Three blood emojis. 🩸🩸🩸 I stared at them for longer than makes sense. Blood emojis. Who sends blood emojis? Who sends anything at 12:03 AM, for that matter? I considered the possibilities in descending order of probability: a wrong number (unlikely, since no one texts wrong numbers at midnight), a glitch (possible, though glitches usually don't send coherent symbols), a joke (likely, but I couldn't think of anyone who would find this funny), or something else I wasn't considering because I was too tired to think properly. I tapped the message. No reply option, just the three drops of blood against a white background, vivid and strange. I put the phone face-down on my chest and stared at the ceiling. My heart was beating faster than it should have been, which annoyed me, because there was no reason for it. It was probably nothing. It was almost certainly nothing. People didn't get haunted by blood emojis. That wasn't a thing. I fell asleep eventually, though I don't remember when, and when I woke up at 6:15 to my alarm, the message was still there, glowing from my lock screen like an accusation. --- The Budget Express was out of the sandwich I wanted—the one with the specific combination of ingredients that made it tolerable—so I bought a cheese pasty instead, which cost £2.85 and was probably designed by someone who had never eaten a meal in their life. I ate it standing in the car park while watching a group of younger kids board the school bus, their faces arranged in the particular expressions of misery that characterized every school morning for everyone, everywhere, I suspected. The pasty was bad. I ate it anyway because I was hungry and had forgotten my actual lunch and this was my own fault for forgetting and now I had to live with the consequences. The Maths lesson was double period, which meant two hours of trigonometry, which I had been failing to understand for three weeks despite paying attention, taking notes, and doing the homework. Ms. Patel was explaining something aboutSOHCAHTOA that I had heard before and would hear again and would never, apparently, comprehend. My mind kept drifting to the phone in my pocket, which was stupid. It was a text. Three emojis. Nothing had changed. And yet I found myself thinking about it in ways I hadn't thought about anything in months, maybe years—not with fascination exactly, more with the kind of obsessive attention you give to something that doesn't make sense. I could tell Priya. I was sitting next to her, and she was taking notes in her careful handwriting, and I could have leaned over and said, *Hey, did I tell you I got a weird text last night?* But I didn't, because she would make a whole thing of it. Priya believed in things—she had a whole folder on her phone of ghost stories and urban legends and theories about the Bleakford pier—and I could already picture her face, the way her eyes would light up, the way she would start asking questions I didn't want to answer. I didn't want it to be a thing. I wanted it to be nothing, which it probably was, and that was that. The pasty was sitting in my stomach like a small regret by the time the lesson ended. --- My father was distracted at dinner, which was normal for him these days. He was always distracted now, always checking his phone under the table, always sighing at moments that didn't call for sighing. My mother was talking about the community center's funding application, which had been pending for three months and which she was treating like a personal relationship that had recently become complicated. "The thing is," she said, stirring her tea in that specific way she had, the seven-minute method she insisted on even when guests were waiting, "they keep changing the criteria. Every time I think I've met the requirements, they add something new. It's like they don't actually want anyone to get funding. They just want people to apply." "Right," my father said. He was looking at his plate. "The councilwoman I spoke to, Karen—she's lovely, really—but she kept making these faces. You know the kind. The 'I can't actually help you but I'm going to pretend I want to' face." "Right," my father said again. I ate my pasta and didn't say anything. I was thinking about the text, which was irritating, because there was nothing to think about. My parents had their own things—my father's mysterious work troubles, my mother's volunteer project—and I had mine, which were probably nothing and would probably turn out to be nothing, and that was fine. I didn't need to burden them with a weird text that was probably just a glitch or a wrong number or someone's idea of a joke. "Is the pasta okay, love?" my mother asked, looking at me with that specific expression she got when she was worried about something but trying not to show it. "It's fine," I said. "You seem a bit distracted." "I'm tired." "Exams coming up." "Something like that." She nodded and went back to her funding application. My father finished his pasta, excused himself, and went to his home office, closing the door behind him. I listened to the sound of his keyboard clicking—work emails at 8 PM, apparently, because something was always happening at work now. I washed my plate and put it in the drying rack and went upstairs to my bedroom, where I sat on my bed and looked at my phone for longer than was reasonable. The message was still there. 🩸🩸🩸 I turned the phone over and lay back on my pillow. The ceiling had a water stain in the corner that I'd been staring at for years, trying to determine if it was growing or just staying the same. It looked the same as always—a vaguely kidney-shaped discoloration that some previous tenant must have caused and that my parents had never gotten around to mentioning to anyone who could fix it. I fell asleep thinking about the text, which was stupid, and which I was going to forget about by morning, and which was almost certainly nothing.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This opening chapter demonstrates strong technical competence and establishes an authentic teenage voice that aligns well with the darkly comic British YA brief. The protagonist's narration captures the particular blend of analytical detachment and underlying anxiety that characterizes many intelligent adolescents, with convincing details like counting things unconsciously and the specific irritation with a £2.85 cheese pasty. The writing successfully avoids several common pitfalls. There's no forced poetry or purple prose - the language remains grounded and naturalistic throughout. The protagonist's voice feels genuine rather than artificially witty, with observations that emerge organically from character rather than authorial showing-off. The family dinner scene particularly succeeds in showing rather than telling, revealing the parents' preoccupations and the protagonist's isolation through behavior and dialogue rather than exposition. However, the chapter suffers from a lack of forward momentum. While the mysterious text provides the inciting incident, the protagonist's reaction is so determinedly rational and dismissive that it drains tension from the narrative. The repeated insistence that "it's probably nothing" becomes somewhat tedious, and while this may be psychologically realistic, it doesn't serve the story's dramatic needs effectively. The characterization aligns well with the provided profiles, particularly the protagonist's commitment to rationality as a defense mechanism. The parents feel authentic in their distraction and preoccupation with their own concerns. The writing demonstrates good control of pacing within scenes, though the overall chapter arc feels somewhat static. The dark comedy promised in the prompt is largely absent from this opening, which reads more as straight contemporary realism. While this may be intentional setup, it doesn't fully deliver on the genre expectations established by the brief. The chapter does establish the unsettling atmosphere effectively through the protagonist's growing obsession with the text despite their rational dismissal of it. The prose is clean and competent throughout, with no significant technical issues. The voice remains consistent and the domestic details feel lived-in and authentic. However, the chapter doesn't take many creative risks or surprise the reader in meaningful ways. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 13 Compelling Plot: 11 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 12 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 16 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 13

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter Two Four nights passed before the second message. I had almost convinced myself it was a fluke—a one-time glitch, a wrong number, someone's idea of a joke I didn't understand. I had stopped thinking about it, mostly, during the day, though I still checked my phone before bed like a ritual I hadn't chosen. The second text arrived at 12:17 AM. 🩸🩸🩸 I was awake instantly, which meant I hadn't been sleeping, which meant I had been waiting, which I refused to acknowledge even to myself. The message sat on my screen, patient and unexplained. I didn't respond. I didn't know what I would say. I turned the phone over and made myself think about something else, which took approximately forty-five seconds before I was thinking about it again. The third message came two nights later, at 12:09 AM. The fourth the night after that, at 12:33 AM. A pattern was emerging, though I resisted calling it that—resisted writing it down, resisted acknowledging that I had noticed. But I did notice. I noticed everything, that was the problem, and I couldn't stop noticing even when noticing made things worse. By the sixth message, I had bought a notebook. A small one, the kind with a cardboard cover and unlined pages, which I hid in my desk drawer behind a stack of revision notes I hadn't looked at in weeks. I recorded the dates and times in my careful handwriting: *Night 1: 12:03 AM. Night 2: 12:17 AM. Night 3: 12:09 AM. Night 4: 12:33 AM.* The entries were sparse and factual, the kind of record you might keep for an insurance claim or a scientific experiment. I didn't write down what I felt when the messages arrived, because I didn't want to know what I felt, and also because I wasn't sure I had the words for it. The messages always came from the same number. I had tried to trace it, obviously—I had a Gmail account specifically for spam and suspicious activity, and I ran the number through every reverse lookup site I could find. The results were the same every time: *Number not found* or *This number may be disconnected.* One site told me the number didn't exist. Another told me it was registered to a name that didn't match any address I could verify. I considered calling it, late at night, just to hear what would happen, but I never quite worked up the nerve. Engaging with it felt like admitting it was real, and I wasn't ready to admit that. --- The collision with Jade Hart happened on a Tuesday, in the corridor between the Humanities block and the main entrance. It wasn't dramatic—I was looking at my phone, checking the messages again even though I knew nothing would have changed, and she was walking fast with her head down, and we collided shoulder-to-shoulder with the dull impact of two bodies meeting unexpectedly. "Oh," she said, and her voice was sharp, ready to be angry, and then she looked at me and something shifted in her face. Not guilt exactly, but a kind of recognition, like she had been caught doing something she shouldn't be doing. "It's you." "Hi, Jade," I said. I didn't know what else to say. We had never been friends, had never even been acquaintances, but we knew each other the way everyone in our year knew each other—through proximity, through shared spaces, through the vague social mapping that determined who sat with whom at lunch and who spoke to whom in the corridors. "Scholarship kid," she said, and her voice was cruel but also strange, the cruelty not quite landing the way it usually did. She looked tired, I noticed. There were dark circles under her eyes, the kind that came from not sleeping, and her hand was shaking slightly as she adjusted the strap of her bag. "Always wandering around like you don't know where you're going." "Sorry," I said, because I didn't want an argument. I had never wanted an argument with anyone, really, but especially not with Jade Hart, whose family owned half the town and who could make my life difficult in ways that didn't bear thinking about. She looked at me for a moment longer, and I had the strange feeling that she was going to say something else—something different, something that wasn't a insult. But then the moment passed, and she shook her head, and her face rearranged itself into its usual arrangement of contempt. "Just watch where you're going," she said, and she walked away before I could respond. I stood in the corridor for a few seconds, holding my phone, wondering what that had been about. Jade Hart was not a nice person—I had known her since primary school, and she had been cruel for as long as I could remember—but she had never seemed frightened before. That was what I had seen in her face, I realized. Fear. The kind of fear that didn't belong in the eyes of someone whose family owned half the seafront. I pushed the thought aside. It was probably nothing. She probably had exams coming up, or family problems, or any of the thousand things that made people look tired and frightened. It wasn't my business. I had my own things to worry about. --- The seventh message came at 12:01 AM, and I was ready for it. I had been sitting up in bed for twenty minutes, pretending to read a book I wasn't really reading, waiting. When the notification appeared, I didn't jump. I just picked up the phone and looked at the screen and felt something I didn't have a name for—not fear exactly, not yet, but something close to it. I typed without thinking: *Who is this?* The response came immediately, faster than any human could have typed it, and the message on my screen was not what I had expected. Not 🩸🩸🩸, not a joke, not a wrong number. HELP. Just that. HELP. Eight letters, white on black, glowing from my phone like a signal I didn't know how to receive. I stared at it for a long time. I tried to think of a response—*Help with what? Who is this? Where are you?*—but my fingers wouldn't move, and the moment passed, and no more messages came. The screen went dark, and I sat there in the darkness of my bedroom, holding a phone that had just asked me for help, and I didn't know what to do. I didn't sleep that night. I sat with my back against the headboard and my phone in my hand, waiting for another message that didn't come, and I told myself it was nothing, it was probably nothing, but I didn't believe it anymore.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong technical competence and careful adherence to both the character profiles and chapter plan. The protagonist's voice is consistently rendered - their methodical nature comes through in the detailed record-keeping of the messages, their skepticism in the attempts to rationalize and research the phenomenon, and their reluctance to engage emotionally with what's happening. The writing maintains the promised "dry detachment" while allowing glimpses of underlying fear. The escalation is well-paced, moving from isolated incidents to pattern recognition to direct engagement. The protagonist's decision to finally respond feels earned rather than arbitrary, emerging from their methodical nature rather than sudden courage. The collision with Jade Hart serves multiple purposes - advancing the subplot while revealing both characters' hidden vulnerabilities. However, the chapter suffers from some significant weaknesses. The prose occasionally veers toward overwrought territory, particularly in passages like "holding a phone that had just asked me for help" which feels artificially dramatic. The protagonist's voice, while consistent, can become monotonous - their analytical detachment, while character-appropriate, sometimes distances the reader from emotional engagement. The dialogue with Jade Hart feels somewhat stilted and expository. Her "scholarship kid" comment lands awkwardly, feeling more like a plot device to establish class dynamics than natural speech. The protagonist's responses are appropriately passive but lack the subtle complexity promised in the character profile. The chapter follows its plan faithfully but perhaps too rigidly - the beats feel mechanical rather than organic. The supernatural elements are handled with appropriate restraint, maintaining ambiguity without being frustratingly vague. The ending moment with "HELP" provides genuine tension and a strong hook. The writing demonstrates competent craft but lacks the spark of genuine creativity. It's well-executed genre fiction that hits its marks without transcending them. The dark comedy promised in the prompt is largely absent - while the protagonist's dry observations occasionally amuse, there's little of the "genuinely funny" moments the plan promised. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 12 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 13 Tell-Don't-Show: 12 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 13 Amateurish: 11 Purple Prose: 12 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 10 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 13 Characters Consistent with Profile: 16 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 14

Chapter 3

Ok now chapter 3. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter Three I told Priya at lunch the next day. We were sitting at our usual table, the one near the window that caught the light but was also near the heat vent, which meant it was always either too hot or too cold depending on the season. She was eating a sandwich her mother had made—the same sandwich her mother had been making since we were twelve, some kind of chickpea mixture that Priya claimed was delicious but that smelled like feet—and I was picking at a yoghurt I wasn't hungry for. "I got a text," I said, and then I stopped, because I didn't know how to continue. How do you tell someone that you've been receiving mysterious messages that might be supernatural? How do you start that sentence? Priya looked at me, her mouth full of sandwich. "What kind of text?" "I don't know. Weird kind." "Weird how?" I pulled out my phone and scrolled back to the messages. The blood emojis were still there, three of them, patient and inexplicable. Below them, my question and the response: HELP. I turned the phone around and slid it across the table. She looked at it for a long time. Her face did something complicated—concern, then interest, then something that looked almost like excitement, which annoyed me immediately because this wasn't exciting, this was strange and unsettling and I didn't like it. "Okay," she said slowly. "Okay. That's—wow." "It's probably nothing." "It's probably not nothing." "Priya—" "No, listen to me. You know what this is? This is exactly what I've been saying for years. This town is haunted. Not in the fun way, in the actual way. There's something wrong here. Something that's been wrong since—" She stopped, and her eyes got that look they got when she was thinking hard about something. "What year did you say this started?" "I didn't say. It's been about a week." "A week. That's—" She pulled out her own phone and started typing, her thumbs moving fast. "I need to check something." I watched her research, feeling the particular irritation that came from telling someone something and having them immediately transform it into their own project. This was Priya's way—she took everything and made it her business, which was sometimes helpful and sometimes exhausting and always impossible to stop. "Here," she said, turning her phone around. "1987. A teenager drowned near the pier. Marcus Chen. It was ruled accidental, but there were rumors—look, there are articles here, but they're all really short, like someone told the papers not to dig too deep." I looked at the screen. The photograph was grainy, obviously scanned from a newspaper, and the boy in it was seventeen years old and dead and none of this was my business. But I couldn't look away. "I don't see how this is connected," I said. "The phone number. Let me see if I can trace it." "I already tried. It's not traceable." "Let me try anyway." I gave her the number. She typed it into three different sites, each more specialized than the last, and each one came back with the same result: number not found, number disconnected, number may not exist. But Priya didn't seem discouraged. If anything, she seemed more convinced. "This is supernatural," she said. "This is definitely supernatural. A number that doesn't exist, sending messages about a boy who died in 1987—it's like he's trying to contact someone. And you're the someone he contacted." "That's ridiculous." "It's the only thing that makes sense." I took back my phone and put it in my pocket. My yoghurt was sitting untouched, the surface developing a skin that matched my mood. Priya was looking at me with that expression she got when she was right about something and knew she was right and was waiting for me to admit it. I wasn't going to admit anything. I didn't know what was happening, but I knew it wasn't supernatural, it couldn't be supernatural, because supernatural things didn't exist and I was not going to start believing in them now. "I'm not talking about this anymore," I said. "That's fine. But you're going to keep getting those texts. And something is going to happen eventually. And when it does, I'm going to be right here, saying I told you so." I didn't respond. I threw away my yoghurt and went to my next lesson, and I spent the entire hour thinking about Marcus Chen, seventeen years old, drowned near the pier, and wondering why a dead boy was texting me. --- That night, I woke at 3 AM. I didn't know what had woken me—I hadn't been dreaming, as far as I could tell, and my alarm wasn't set to go off for another three hours. I lay there in the darkness, listening to my own breathing, feeling the weight of my blankets and the coolness of the air and something else, something that felt like presence, like I wasn't alone in the room. I reached for my phone and turned on the torch. The beam cut through the darkness and landed on my window, and my breath caught in my throat. The window was open. I was certain I had closed it. I always closed it—I was cautious about things like that, about security, about leaving things the way they were supposed to be. But there it was, the curtains billowing slightly in the night breeze, the window wide open despite the fact that I had closed it before bed, despite the fact that I remembered closing it, despite the fact that I was the kind of person who remembered things like that. I got out of bed and walked toward the window, and that's when I saw it. The glass was fogged. Not partially fogged, not the way glass gets fogged when there's a temperature difference between inside and out—fully fogged, the entire surface covered in a layer of condensation that shouldn't have been there because the night was warm, warm enough that I hadn't needed a blanket, and windows don't fog in warm weather. I reached out and touched the glass, and my finger left a smear, and through the smear I could see the word that had been written there, traced in the fog like a message from someone who couldn't find any other way to communicate. HELP. Just like the text. Just like the word that had appeared on my phone twelve hours earlier. I stood there with my finger on the glass and my heart beating too fast and my rational mind telling me there was an explanation, there had to be an explanation, but for the first time in longer than I could remember, I couldn't find one. I cleaned the window myself. I used a towel from the bathroom, wiping away the condensation until the glass was clear again, until there was no evidence that anything had happened except my own shaking hands and the memory of what I had seen. I closed the window and locked it and stood there for a long moment, looking at the clear glass, waiting for something else to happen. Nothing happened. I went back to bed and sat with my back against the headboard and my phone in my hand, and I didn't sleep. I thought about Marcus Chen and the texts and the word written on my window, and I thought about Priya's face when she said *this is supernatural*, and I thought about how much I wanted her to be wrong and how sure I was that she wasn't. Somewhere in the house, a door closed. Somewhere outside, the fog rolled in from the sea. And I sat there in the darkness, waiting for dawn, and wondered what was going to happen next.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 3)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong technical competence and character consistency, but falls short of the ambitious tonal goals outlined in the writing plan. The prose is clean and readable, with a convincing teenage voice that maintains the protagonist's established skepticism and dry detachment. The dialogue between the protagonist and Priya feels natural and captures their relationship dynamic well - Priya's enthusiasm contrasting with the protagonist's resistance. However, the chapter struggles with several significant issues. Most critically, it fails to deliver on the "darkly comic" promise of the prompt. While the protagonist's voice has moments of dry observation, there's virtually no humor present - neither the organic character-driven comedy nor the failed attempts at humor that the plan specifically called for. The tone remains consistently serious and mildly anxious throughout. The supernatural elements, while atmospheric, lean heavily into conventional horror tropes. The fogged window with "HELP" written in condensation is a familiar ghost story beat that doesn't feel particularly fresh or unsettling in the way the plan promised. The writing becomes somewhat overwrought during the supernatural sequence, with phrases like "my heart beating too fast and my rational mind telling me there was an explanation" that edge toward purple prose. The chapter does succeed in maintaining character consistency. The protagonist's methodical skepticism and Priya's immediate belief in the supernatural align perfectly with their established profiles. The pacing is solid, building from the lunch conversation to the nighttime manifestation effectively. The plot advancement feels somewhat mechanical - we get the expected research revelation about Marcus Chen and the escalation to physical manifestations, but these beats don't surprise or illuminate character in unexpected ways. The protagonist's internal conflict between rationality and growing fear is well-handled but predictable. The writing shows competence but lacks the distinctive voice and tonal complexity that would elevate it. It reads like solid YA supernatural fiction but doesn't achieve the specific darkly comic British sensibility it was aiming for. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 12 Compelling Plot: 11 Coherent: 16 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 8 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12 Amateurish: 8 Purple Prose: 9 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 7 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 8 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 11 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 9

Chapter 4

Ok now chapter 4. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter Four Priya was waiting for me at the library entrance, which was annoying because I had told her I was going alone. She had this way of inserting herself into situations that I had not invited her into, a kind of gravitational pull toward involvement that I had been fighting since we were eleven years old and she had decided we were going to be friends whether I liked it or not. "I looked up more stuff," she said, falling into step beside me as I pushed through the doors. "The Marcus Chen thing—there's a photograph. I found it in one of the archived papers. It's not great quality, but it's him. That's definitely him." "Why are you here?" "Because you're my friend and you're clearly not okay and I'm not going to let you investigate mysterious deaths alone." "I didn't ask you to." "You never ask for anything. That's your problem." I didn't respond to that because it was probably true. We walked through the library in silence, past the returns bin and the children's section and the magazines nobody read, until we reached the computer terminals in the back corner where the old microfiche machines sat like relics from another era. Priya had already pulled up the image on one of the screens—a grainy black-and-white photograph of a teenage boy, clearly taken in a hurry, clearly not intended for publication. I looked at his face and felt something I couldn't name. He was ordinary, that's what struck me first. Not haunting, not sinister, just a kid who had died thirty-seven years ago and whose photograph had been preserved in a library archive because someone had thought it might be important. He had the kind of face that would have been forgettable in any other context—round cheeks, short hair, the generic features of a generation I had never known. But there was something in his eyes, something that looked almost like urgency, like he had known something was going to happen and had been trying to tell someone before it was too late. "That's him," Priya said quietly. "That's who keeps texting you." "We don't know that." "The number. The timing. It's him. It has to be him." I stared at the photograph for another moment and then looked away. The library smelled like dust and old paper and the particular staleness of spaces that were used by people who had nowhere else to go. I could see Mrs. Okonkwo at the front desk, watching us with an expression I couldn't read. "I'm going to try calling the number," I said. "Now?" "While I'm here. If it connects to something weird, at least I'll have witness." Priya nodded, and I pulled out my phone and scrolled to the number. My thumb hovered over the call button for a moment, and I felt the particular dread of doing something you can't undo. Then I pressed it. The phone rang once. Twice. Three times. I was about to hang up when the ringing stopped, and the silence that followed was not the silence of a disconnected line. It was the silence of something waiting. I could hear something on the other end. It might have been breathing—that soft, rhythmic sound of air moving in and out of lungs. Or it might have been static, the background noise of a connection that wasn't quite right. Or it might have been neither, something else entirely, something I didn't have a name for. "Hello?" I said, and my voice sounded strange in the quiet of the library, too loud, too uncertain. The breathing continued. Or the static continued. Or whatever it was continued, and then I heard something else—a voice, maybe, or the impression of a voice, words spoken too quickly and too softly to understand. It might have been my name. It might have been nothing. I hung up. My hand was shaking, which I hated, because shaking hands meant I was frightened and I didn't want to be frightened, I didn't want any of this to be real. "What did they say?" Priya asked. "Nothing. They didn't say anything." "That's not nothing. That's something." "I know." We sat there in the silence of the library, and I held a phone that had just connected me to something I couldn't explain, and I wondered what I was supposed to do next. --- Mr. Hassan lived on the outskirts of town, in a house that had once been nice and had slowly, over the years, become something else. The garden was overgrown, the paint was peeling, and there was a layer of dust on the windows that suggested they hadn't been cleaned in months. I stood on the front step and rang the doorbell three times, and no one answered. I had found his address through a combination of reverse phone lookup and asking around—the retired police officer who had worked the Marcus Chen case was not a secret, apparently, just forgotten. People remembered him when I mentioned the name, nodded and said yes, he lived out there, on the edge of town, the one with the cats. No one answered the door. I waited for five minutes, ten, ringing the bell at intervals, looking through the windows at the darkened interior. I could see furniture covered in sheets, boxes stacked in corners, the kind of house that had been slowly emptied of life until only the essentials remained. I left a note. I wrote my name and my phone number on the back of an old receipt and stuffed it through the door crack. *I want to talk about Marcus Chen,* I wrote. *Please call me.* It felt inadequate, a message for an event that was beyond adequate. I came back the next day. No answer. I came back the day after that, standing on the porch for longer than was comfortable, ringing the doorbell until my finger ached. And on the third day, finally, the door opened. The man who stood in the doorway was old—older than I had expected, older than seventy-four should have looked, though I didn't know what seventy-four was supposed to look like. His back was bent, his face was lined, and his eyes held something I recognized but couldn't name. Tiredness, maybe. Or waiting. The particular exhaustion of someone who had been carrying something for a long time. "You're the one who's been calling," he said. It wasn't a question. "I wrote a note." "I got your note." "Can I come in?" He looked at me for a long moment, and I had the feeling that he was deciding something, weighing the costs and benefits of letting a stranger into his house. Then he stepped aside and gestured for me to follow. The inside of the house was worse than the outside. There were boxes everywhere, and photographs on the walls that he had apparently never unpacked, and three cats who watched me with the flat, unblinking eyes of creatures who had seen too much. Mr. Hassan sat down in a chair by the window—a chair that was clearly his, shaped to his body, worn in the places where he sat—and he looked at me with eyes that held thirty-seven years of something I didn't understand. "What do you want to know?" he asked. "Everything," I said. "I want to know everything." He laughed, but there was no humor in it. "That's a dangerous thing to want."
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 4)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong technical competence and character consistency, but falls short of the ambitious tonal goals outlined in the writing plan. The prose is clean and controlled, with the protagonist's voice maintaining the dry, skeptical tone established in earlier chapters. The pacing moves effectively between the library research scene and the encounter with Mr. Hassan, building tension appropriately. The characterization remains consistent with the established profiles. The protagonist's reluctance and methodical approach feels authentic, as does Priya's persistent involvement despite being told to stay away. Mr. Hassan's introduction effectively conveys decades of guilt and weariness without overstatement. The dialogue feels natural, particularly the protagonist's clipped responses and Mr. Hassan's weary directness. However, the chapter struggles with the "darkly comic" mandate from the prompt. While the writing maintains the protagonist's sardonic internal voice ("which was annoying because I had told her I was going alone"), it never achieves genuine humor that emerges organically from character and situation as promised in the plan. The dark elements work better - the eerie phone call, the deteriorating house, the weight of Mr. Hassan's guilt - but even these feel somewhat restrained. The supernatural elements are handled with appropriate ambiguity. The phone call scene effectively creates unease without over-explaining, and the description of hearing "something that might have been breathing" maintains the story's commitment to uncertainty about what's actually happening. The writing occasionally veers toward telling rather than showing, particularly in describing Mr. Hassan's appearance and emotional state. Phrases like "his eyes held something I recognized but couldn't name" and "the particular exhaustion of someone who had been carrying something for a long time" feel slightly overwrought and explanatory rather than allowing the reader to infer these qualities from concrete details. The chapter follows its plan faithfully, hitting all the required plot points: the library research, the failed attempts to contact Mr. Hassan, and finally the breakthrough meeting. The pacing feels appropriate for building toward the revelation promised in the next chapter. The prose style is competent but not particularly distinctive. While it avoids purple prose and forced metaphors, it also lacks the sharp wit or genuine darkness that would elevate it beyond solid but unremarkable YA fiction. The writing feels safe rather than taking the risks necessary to achieve the "genuinely unsettling" and "honestly funny" qualities the plan promises. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 13 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 8 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 10 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 9 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 11

Chapter 5

Ok now chapter 5. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter Five I came back the next day. No answer. I came back the day after that, standing on the porch for fifteen minutes, twenty, ringing the doorbell until my finger went numb from pressing. The windows stayed dark. The cats didn't appear. The house sat at the edge of Bleakford like a thing that had given up on being a home. On the third day, I was about to leave—had actually turned around, had actually started walking back toward the road—when I heard the sound of a door opening behind me. He stood in the doorway, and he was exactly as tired as I remembered, but there was something else in his face now. Not hostility, not welcome, just the exhaustion of someone who had been putting something off for too long and had finally run out of excuses. "You again," he said. "I left a note." "I got your note." "Can I come in?" He looked at me for a long moment, and I had the feeling that he was deciding something—not whether to let me in, but something bigger, something that would change things regardless of what he decided. Then he stepped aside and gestured for me to follow. The inside of the house was worse than I had remembered. There were boxes everywhere, stacked against walls and stacked in corners, and photographs on the walls that he had apparently never unpacked—portraits of people I didn't recognize, scenes from a life that had been slowly emptied of everything except the furniture. Three cats watched me from the window ledge, their eyes flat and unblinking, the eyes of creatures who had seen too much to be surprised by anything anymore. Mr. Hassan sat down in a chair by the window—a chair that was clearly his, worn in the shape of his body, positioned to catch the light that never quite reached this part of the house. He didn't offer me a seat. I didn't ask for one. "I don't know anything," he said. His voice was flat, rehearsed, like he had said these words before, to other people, at other times. "You should forget about it. All of it." "That's not helpful." "It's not meant to be helpful. It's meant to be true." I stood there in his cluttered living room, looking at an old man who was trying to protect something—himself, maybe, or his memories, or the fragile peace he had made with whatever had happened in 1987. I thought about the texts on my phone. I thought about the word written on my window. I thought about Marcus Chen, seventeen years old, drowned near the pier, and I felt something I hadn't felt before: not fear, not curiosity, but anger. Anger at this man for knowing something he wouldn't tell me. Anger at the situation I had somehow found myself in. Anger at myself for not being able to let it go. "Someone died," I said. "Someone who was seventeen years old, and the case was closed, and everyone forgot about it, and now someone is texting me from a number that doesn't exist, and you're telling me to forget about it. That's not good enough." He flinched. It was subtle, almost invisible, but I saw it—the way his face tightened, the way his hands clenched on the arms of his chair.
