This chapter alternates between Devon's cautious research into Voss's collection and their increasingly long conversations at The Anchor. Marlon is evasive about his past but unguarded about his present—the loneliness, the attempts at going straight, the way he's been sober for three years but still feels haunted. The attraction builds through resistance: Devon doesn't trust his own judgment, Marlon doesn't trust anyone. *Word count focus: Deepening both characters through contrast (caution vs. risk), establishing the external plot's parameters, building trust through honesty about what's missing rather than what's happened.* **Chapter Three: The Shape of Things** The planning phase. Devon researches Voss's estate, his security, his schedule. Marlon reconnects with old contacts who might provide access—a retired guard, a former fence, a hacker who can pull building blueprints. These scenes introduce the broader world of small-time crime and the queer subculture that existed within it. Devon meets some of Marlon's people: Esther, a drag queen who runs a community fridge and knows everyone's business; Jerome, a ceramics teacher at a community college who spent fifteen years in federal prison for fraud; Thalia and Ren, a young couple who help with digital security and mock Devon's "museum brain." The romance intensifies through proximity—Devon staying late at Marlon's apartment, watching him sketch floor plans, arguing about the ethics of theft when the original theft was never prosecuted. The chapter ends with a near-miss: Voss's security company notices someone asking questions, and Marlon and Devon have to disappear for a night. *Word count focus: World-building through character introduction, the mechanics of the heist without becoming procedural, the relationship developing through collaboration and conflict.* **Chapter Four: What You Want from Me** The first major romantic beat. They've been circling each other for weeks, and the tension becomes unbearable. During a stakeout in Marlon's car, watching Voss's estate, Devon leans over and kisses him. Marlon pulls away—not because he doesn't want to, but because he does. He tells Devon the truth: everyone who gets close to him gets burned. His last relationship ended when his ex took the fall for one of Marlon's cons. He doesn't trust himself to be good for anyone. Devon, for once, doesn't back down. He tells Marlon about his own damage—the safe marriage, the years of not seeing himself, the way he's spent his whole life choosing what won't hurt him and ending up numb. They sleep together for the first time. It's tender and rough and uncertain, and afterward, Marlon falls asleep smoking, and Devon watches him and thinks about what it means to want someone this badly. *Word count focus: The emotional confession, the physical intimacy, the vulnerability afterward, the stakes of choosing each other when both know it might end badly.* **Chapter Five: The Way Down** Complications multiply. Voss's people identify Marlon from old photographs—his face is known in certain circles, and his attempt to go straight was never total. A message arrives: return what you took or face consequences. At the same time, Devon's museum job is reviewed; his unexplained absences and questions about the collection have raised flags. He's put on administrative leave pending an investigation into his conduct. Marlon pushes Devon to step back—to let Marlon finish this alone, to protect what remains of Devon's careful life. Devon refuses, but the fight exposes how little they actually trust each other. Marlon's instinct is to sacrifice himself; Devon's instinct is to control. They separate, bitter and uncertain, for three days. *Word count focus: External pressure (Voss, the museum), internal conflict (trust, sacrifice, control), the relationship at its breaking point, no easy resolution.* **Chapter Six: What Holds** Marlon goes to Esther for advice; she tells him he's being a coward in the name of being noble. Devon reconnects with an old friend, a curator named Jules who represents the life Devon could have had—stable, respected, expected. Jules sees Devon's distress and offers him a way out: a job in Seattle, a fresh start, an escape from whatever mess he's gotten into. Devon realizes, standing in Jules's bright apartment, that he doesn't want that life anymore. He wants the risk, the uncertainty, the feeling of being alive. He returns to Marlon's apartment unannounced. They don't apologize—not in words—but they sit together in the dark, and Marlon puts out his cigarette, and they hold each other. The chapter ends with a plan: they need inside help, someone on the inside of Voss's estate. They know someone who might fit the bill. *Word count focus: The choice Devon makes, the rejection of safety, the reunion, the renewed commitment to the plan with clear eyes about the risks.* **Chapter Seven: Smoke and Mirrors** The heist itself. The inside help is Jerome's nephew, a young guard named Marcus who needs money and doesn't ask questions. The plan is simple: Voss hosts a charity gala; most of his security will be occupied. Devon, as a museum professional, has a plausible reason to be at the event as a guest. Marlon provides distraction—a minor emergency in another part of the estate—while Devon slips into Voss's private gallery. But nothing goes exactly to plan. Devon finds the painting, but Voss has added new security since they last surveyed. Marcus gets nervous. And Devon has to make a choice: take the painting and run, or stay and disable the alarm, risking everything. He stays. The tension peaks: Marlon, waiting in the car, ready to drive but not knowing if Devon will appear. Devon, hands shaking, working the alarm system. The escape is messy but successful. They meet at a prearranged location, the painting in the back seat, and Marlon looks at Devon like he's seeing him for the first time. *Word count focus: Heist tension and pacing, the intimacy of the collaboration, the moment of choice Devon makes, the physical and emotional aftermath.* **Chapter Eight: After the Rain** Resolution. The painting is returned—not to a museum, but to the artist's surviving family, a sister in Oakland who didn't know the portrait existed. Marlon makes the handoff in person; Devon waits in the car. Afterward, they drive to the coast, to a rented cabin where no one knows them. There's still fallout: Voss's people are looking for them, though the painting's provenance is now documented and Voss can't pursue it publicly. Devon's career is likely over, but he's applied to work with an arts nonprofit focused on returning stolen works to their communities. Marlon is Marlon—he's still smoke and still bad ideas, but he's also here, choosing to stay, choosing to build something uncertain instead of burning it down. The ending is quiet: they sit on the cabin's porch, watching the rain, not talking about the future because the future is already here. Marlon stubs out his last cigarette (for now, maybe, probably not forever) and takes Devon's hand. *Word count focus: Emotional resolution without tidy answers, the aftermath and what comes next, the intimacy of quiet choices, the final image of two people together in the rain.*
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
# Critique and Humanization Analysis ## How a Human Might Approach This Piece A human writer approaching "He was all cigarette smoke and bad ideas" would likely begin from a very different place than an LLM attempting the same prompt. The human would bring something specific to the work—perhaps a memory of someone they knew who fit that description, or a period in their own life when they were drawn to danger, or a specific bar or city that carries emotional weight. The starting point wouldn't be "write a queer neo-noir romance" but rather "I want to explore this feeling I had once, when I met someone who made me feel alive and terrified at the same time." The prompt would be a springboard, not a template. From there, a human would write unevenly. They might draft the ending first because they know where the emotional journey needs to land. They might get stuck on chapter three and skip to chapter six, then realize chapter three needs to change entirely. Their prose would shift based on their energy levels, their mood, what they ate for breakfast, whether their cat knocked over a lamp that morning. The final product would carry the traces of this struggle—maybe a chapter that runs too long, a metaphor that's used twice too many, a moment of surprising brilliance followed by a passage that just gets the job done. A human would also make choices that don't fully make sense to them. They might write a scene that doesn't advance the plot because the character demanded it. They might give a supporting character a speech that reveals something about the writer's own life, not the character's. They might end a chapter on an ambiguous note not because they've planned a reveal later but because they're genuinely unsure what happens next and want to find out as they write. The most important difference: a human writer would be willing to write something that doesn't work. They would have the courage to be bad in the service of being real. An LLM, by contrast, optimizes for competent. It will never write something genuinely strange or uncomfortable, because its training has taught it to predict what should come next in a way that satisfies broad expectations. The result is writing that is perpetually almost good—polished, professional, hitting all the notes—but rarely transcendent. ## Telltale LLM Approaches and Their Pitfalls ### The Safety Problem LLMs are trained to be helpful, which means they avoid giving offense. In creative writing, this manifests as an aversion to anything that might feel too dark, too raw, or too ambiguous. Characters become more sympathetic than real people often are. Conflicts resolve because the narrative demands it, not because that's how conflict actually works. Difficult topics are handled with kid gloves, approached but never truly grappled with. The result is writing that feels sanitized. Nothing truly stinks in these stories; no one says something unforgivable and means it; no relationship ends in a way that isn't ultimately for the best. The reader is protected from discomfort, but so is the art. In the context of this prompt, safety might look like making Marlon too sympathetic too quickly, or ensuring that Devon's choices are always justified by the narrative, or handling the criminal elements as a romantic backdrop rather than something with real moral weight. The "bad ideas" in the prompt suggest self-destruction, but an LLM might make that self-destruction aesthetic—tragic but never truly damaging—rather than showing what it actually costs to live that way. ### The Wrapping-Up Problem LLMs love resolution. Given the eight-chapter structure, an LLM would be tempted to ensure that every thread introduced is tied off neatly: the painting returned, the criminals stopped, the relationship secure, the futures bright. This isn't necessarily bad—readers do want some sense of completion—but it can become a kind of narrative hygiene, a compulsive cleanliness that removes the messiness of actual human experience. Real lives don't wrap up. Real relationships don't resolve into permanent happiness. Real attempts at redemption fail as often as they succeed. A human writer might choose to end with genuine uncertainty: Marlon and Devon together but aware that together might not last, the painting returned but Voss still powerful, the future looking both possible and precarious. An LLM might give us the cabin in the rain and the hand-holding and the implication that they've made it, because the pattern suggests that's what comes next. ### The Impressiveness Problem LLMs have access to vast amounts of sophisticated prose, and their training encourages them to produce text that resembles high-quality writing. This can result in prose that is technically excellent but emotionally inert—sentences that are grammatically perfect and metaphorically rich but don't actually make the reader feel anything. The symptoms are familiar: overuse of sensory detail that doesn't deepen characterization, metaphors that are elaborate but empty, sentences that call attention to their own cleverness instead of serving the story. The description of Devon as someone who "notices things—light, texture, the way Marlon holds a cigarette like a prop in a play he's been performing too long" is an example of this tendency. It's a good sentence, but it's also a sentence that shows off. A human writer might write something clunkier but more honest: "Devon noticed things. That was his job, sort of. He noticed the way light fell on a canvas, the way a frame framed or didn't. He noticed the way Marlon held a cigarette like he was holding it for someone else to look at." The difference is subtle but significant. One sentence performs observation; the other is an observation. One is impressive; the other is readable. ### The Consistency Problem LLMs struggle with genuine contradiction. They prefer to produce narratives where events follow logically from previous events, where character motivations are clear, where the world makes sense. This is generally useful but can flatten stories that need contradiction and confusion to feel real. Real people contradict themselves. Real relationships include moments of connection followed by moments of estrangement that don't follow any logic the participants can articulate. Real heists fail in unexpected ways and succeed for reasons no one planned. An LLM might outline a plan and then execute it beat by beat, with minor complications that are ultimately overcome. A human might throw away the plan entirely when the writing takes an unexpected turn and discover something better. ### The Homogeneous Voice Problem Across thousands of tokens, an LLM tends to settle into a consistent voice—usually a polished, slightly elevated version of whatever the prompt established. This voice doesn't vary based on what's being written about. A scene of quiet intimacy sounds the same as a scene of high tension, just with different imagery. The result is prose that feels authored by a machine rather than by a person with different registers for different moments. A human writer's voice shifts with their energy, their mood, the time of day they're writing. A fight scene might be written in short, punchy sentences because the writer is agitated. A quiet scene might meander because the writer is tired. The prose carries the traces of its creation in a way that feels human even when the words themselves are unremarkable. ## Deep Dive: Critique of the Current Plan ### The Characters as Written Marlon Mercer is described as "a man who radiates self-destruction but has decided, finally, to stop burning everything down." This is a compelling concept, but the plan presents him in terms that are almost too coherent. We know exactly why he is the way he is, exactly what he's trying to do, exactly what his arc will be. An LLM would write Marlon consistently sympathetically—we'd understand his self-destruction so well that we'd never doubt he deserves a happy ending. What might be missing: the parts of Marlon that aren't redeemable. Real people who are "all cigarette smoke and bad ideas" aren't just people waiting to be saved. They're people who have made choices that can't be undone, hurt people who didn't deserve it, taken paths that closed doors behind them. A human Marlon might have done things that the narrative doesn't fully excuse, moments where Devon has to choose to be with him anyway, not because Marlon is obviously worthy but because loving him is what Devon wants, even knowing it might not work out. Devon Chen is similarly coherent: "a museum registrar who's been sleepwalking through a cautious life." The plan establishes his arc clearly, from safety to risk. But there's a risk here of making Devon too blank—he exists to be changed by Marlon, to serve the romance. What might be missing: Devon's own complications, his own bad ideas that aren't about Marlon. Maybe he's not just cautious; maybe he's also cruel in small ways, or cowardly in ways that affect the relationship, or someone who has hurt people too. The plan mentions a marriage that ended amicably, but what if it didn't? What if Devon isn't just sleepy-safe but actively responsible for something he's not confronting? The romance beats follow a pattern that's almost too logical: attraction, resistance, confession, intimacy, conflict, separation, reunion. This is a romance structure, and it works, but it leaves little room for the messiness of actual desire. When Devon kisses Marlon in chapter four, the plan says Marlon "pulls away—not because he doesn't want to, but because he does." This is a common romance beat, but it also dodges something. What if Marlon pulls away for a worse reason? What if Devon pulls away first? What if the first kiss is ugly, awkward, unsatisfying, and they have to figure out if there's anything worth pursuing? ### The Plot as Written The external plot—a small-time con artist trying to return a stolen painting to its owners—is well-suited to the romance. It's personal rather than epic, stakes that matter to the characters without threatening the entire world. But the plan's language around the heist is careful in ways that might betray LLM thinking: "the stakes are real but human-scaled," "the plan is simple," "the escape is messy but successful." What might be missing: genuine failure. Real heists go wrong in ways that can't be fixed. Real plans have blind spots. An LLM might structure the heist so that all the complications are overcome, because that's what the structure demands. A human might write a heist where something goes wrong that changes the story entirely—where they get away with the painting but lose something else, or where the success feels hollow, or where the act of taking it back reveals that "returning" stolen property is more complicated than anyone wanted to admit. The plan mentions Harrison Voss as the antagonist but doesn't give him much specificity. He's "a powerful art collector with connections to Marlon's criminal past." This is functional but not interesting. What might be missing: Voss as a human being with his own stakes. Maybe Voss genuinely believes the painting is his—he bought it legally, even if the original acquisition was corrupt. Maybe Voss has his own history with the artist, his own complicated relationship with the portrait. Making Voss a simple villain would be the LLM approach; making him a person would be the human approach. ### The Setting as Written The plan specifies "a small contemporary museum in Portland" and "The Anchor, a dive bar that caters to the city's queer underground." These are specific enough to feel real but not so specific that they require extensive research. The supporting cast includes Maxine (bartender), Esther (drag queen), Jerome (ceramics teacher), Thalia and Ren (young couple), and Marcus (nervous guard). The risk here is creating a world that feels like a set rather than a living place. The Anchor sounds exactly like the kind of dive bar that would exist in a queer neo-noir romance—the name, the function, the community it serves. Esther the drag queen who "runs a community fridge and knows everyone's business" is almost a type. What might be missing: the specific, idiosyncratic details that come from a writer's actual knowledge of these spaces. Maybe The Anchor has a particular smell, a particular sound, a particular regular who always sits in the same chair. Maybe Esther's drag isn't just a characterization but a specific aesthetic that means something. Maybe the community fridge isn't just a plot device but a real place with real history. The plan also mentions "the queer subculture that existed within" criminal circles, which is an interesting historical reference (the AIDS crisis, the way criminal networks sometimes provided for queer people excluded from mainstream economy). But the plan treats this as background rather than something that could be explored in more depth. What might be missing: the specific texture of that history, the way Marlon's past is shaped not just by crime but by the particular conditions that made crime a viable path for queer men of his generation. ### The Tone as Written The plan says the voice is "lyrical but grounded, Devon's interiority filtered through sensory precision rather than hardboiled posturing." It also says "the noir elements (shadow, rain, smoke, moral ambiguity) are present but not performative; they're the natural texture of these characters' lives." And "the sensuality between Devon and Marlon is explicit and integral to the narrative." These are all good intentions, but they describe a tone that might be too consistent. A human writer's tone would shift based on what's happening in the scene. A fight scene wouldn't have the same texture as a tender scene. A moment of danger wouldn't read the same as a moment of quiet conversation. The plan doesn't suggest any variation in register—which might indicate an LLM tendency to produce prose that stays in its chosen lane. The plan also says the prose should "feel like someone who notices things." This is interesting, but it's worth asking: what does Devon notice, and why? The plan suggests light, texture, the way Marlon holds a cigarette. But what about the things Devon doesn't notice, or notices incorrectly? What about his blind spots? A human narrator would have limitations, would misread situations, would see what they want to see. An LLM might produce a narrator who notices perfectly, whose observations are always accurate and illuminating. ### The Arc as Written The plan describes a transformation: Devon from safety to risk, Marlon from self-destruction to redemption. These are classic arcs, and they work. But the plan presents them in terms that are almost too clean. Marlon is "trying to leave his old life," Devon is "finally being seen," the relationship is "the path to that change." What might be missing: the possibility that change doesn't happen, or happens incompletely, or happens and then unravels. The plan says "the answer should be neither simple nor nihilistic—maybe they can, but only if they stop being their own worst enemy." This is a thoughtful intention, but the chapter plan suggests a relatively conventional romance arc where they do stop being their own worst enemy, at least long enough to complete the heist and drive to the coast. The ending—"they sit on the cabin's porch, watching the rain, not talking about the future because the future is already here"—is beautifully phrased, but it might be too neat. What if the future isn't "here"? What if it's uncertain, frightening, likely to fall apart? What if the quiet moment is interrupted by a text message, a noise, a doubt? An LLM might leave us with that perfect image of two people together in the rain. A human might complicate it. ## Brainstorming: Ideas to Make It More Human ### Complicate the Characters Consider making Marlon less sympathetic in ways that the narrative doesn't fully excuse. Perhaps he did something truly terrible in his past—not just fence stolen art but hurt someone, betray someone who trusted him. The plan can acknowledge this without fully explaining it. Devon has to love him anyway, or decide he can't, and either choice is valid. Consider making Devon's past messier too. Perhaps his marriage didn't end amicably. Perhaps he hurt someone, or failed someone, or chose himself when he should have chosen someone else. His caution might not be virtue but fear, and his attraction to Marlon might be as much about running from his past as about running toward something new. Consider adding a flaw to Marlon's redemption arc. Maybe he doesn't actually feel guilty about the painting—he wants it back because it was his, or because the original theft was supposed to be his score, or because returning it gives him something he needs (validation, closure, a story he can tell himself). His desire to "make it right" might be complicated by less noble motivations. Consider making Devon less competent. He's a museum registrar, not a detective. His research skills might hit walls. His plan contributions might be naive. He might mess up in ways that put Marlon at risk. His arc isn't just from safety to risk but from competence to humility, from thinking he can handle this to realizing he can't, from observation to action. ### Complicate the Plot Consider letting the heist fail in a significant way. Maybe they get the painting but lose something else—a connection, a person, a possibility. Maybe the return doesn't go as planned—the artist's sister doesn't want it, or wants something else, or reveals that the artist was complicated too. The painting might not be the clear moral object the plan suggests. Consider introducing a genuine betrayal. Maybe Marcus, the nervous guard, sells them out. Maybe someone in Marlon's network has their own agenda. Maybe Voss is more sympathetic than they expected, or more dangerous, or both. Complications that emerge from character rather than from plot structure would feel more organic. Consider making the aftermath messier. The plan suggests Devon applying to work with an arts nonprofit, but what if that doesn't work out? What if he's fired from the museum and can't find equivalent work? What if the move to the coast is less a romantic gesture than a necessity because they can't stay in the city? What if Marlon's "bad ideas" resurface when the adrenaline fades? Consider adding a subplot that doesn't resolve. Maybe there's a person from Marlon's past who wanted something from him and didn't get it. Maybe Devon's ex-spouse reappears with complications. Maybe the community at The Anchor has its own problems that the main characters can't solve. Stories don't need to resolve every thread, and leaving some loose can make the world feel larger than the plot. ### Complicate the Setting Consider making The Anchor more specific and less archetypal. Maybe it has a particular history—the building used to be something else, the bar has been run by three different owners, there's a particular regular who everyone has a story about. Maybe Maxine isn't just a bartender but a person with her own narrative, someone whose advice is shaped by her own experiences, someone who might be wrong about things. Consider adding a location that isn't part of the heist. Maybe Devon has a favorite place—the museum after hours, a particular park bench, a coffee shop where he used to go with someone else. These places would add texture without advancing the plot, and they might trigger memories or emotions that complicate the present action. Consider making the city itself more present. Portland is mentioned, but what does that mean? The rain, yes, but also the specific neighborhoods, the specific class dynamics, the specific queer geography of the city. Not research-heavy details but sensory ones—the way the light looks in this neighborhood versus that one, the sound of the MAX train, the particular feel of a certain kind of fog. Consider adding a detail that's just strange. Maybe there's a house on Marlon's block that's been abandoned for years, and everyone has a theory about it. Maybe Esther has a collection of something that she never explains. Maybe the painting's artist had a signature that looks like something else entirely. Strange details that don't mean anything but feel real can elevate prose from competent to alive. ### Complicate the Prose Consider varying the sentence length and structure more deliberately. Some sentences should be long and winding, some should be short and sharp. Some paragraphs should be a single sentence; some should be pages. The prose should breathe, should have rhythm, should feel like it's being written by someone who cares about how it sounds. Consider using simpler language in some places. The plan's emphasis on "lyrical" prose might result in a kind of preciousness that distances the reader. Sometimes the most effective sentence is the simplest one. Devon noticing that Marlon is beautiful doesn't need a simile; it just needs to be stated, plainly, honestly. Consider allowing some passages to be rougher than others. A first draft might have inconsistent prose, and that's okay. Better rough and real than polished and hollow. The revision process can even out some inconsistencies, but keeping some roughness can preserve the energy of the original writing. Consider including moments of failed communication. Characters who say one thing and mean another, conversations that go wrong, silence that speaks louder than words. Real dialogue is often ineffective; people mishear, misread, deflect. Showing this can make conversations feel more authentic than exchanges where everyone understands each other perfectly. ### Complicate the Romance Consider making the physical relationship less idealized. First times are often awkward. Desire can be clumsy. Sex can leave one person satisfied and the other uncertain. Showing these complications—not as problems to be overcome but as the actual texture of intimacy—would make the romance feel more real. Consider adding a moment of genuine doubt. Not the conflict-and-reunion structure but a deeper doubt, something that isn't resolved by the end. Maybe Devon isn't sure he's in love; maybe he's in love with the idea of being in love with someone like Marlon. Maybe Marlon isn't sure he can be what Devon needs. Maybe they stay together partly because they're afraid of being alone, and the story doesn't pretend otherwise. Consider making the romance less central to the plot. The plan positions the romance as the emotional core, which is appropriate, but an LLM might make everything revolve around it too carefully. What if there are scenes where the romance isn't present, where the characters are dealing with other things, where the relationship isn't the main event? What if the heist matters for reasons that have nothing to do with their feelings for each other? Consider introducing a genuine incompatibility. Maybe they want different things—Marlon wants to keep moving, Devon wants to stay; Marlon wants to keep the past behind him, Devon wants to understand it. These tensions don't need to be resolved; they can persist, making the relationship feel like an ongoing negotiation rather than a completed achievement. ### Complicate the Ending Consider ending before the cabin scene. Maybe the story ends with the heist complete, the painting returned, and Devon and Marlon in the car, not yet at the coast, not yet safe, not yet sure. The future is genuinely uncertain, and the reader doesn't get to see how it turns out. Consider ending with a complication after the cabin. Maybe they're at the cabin, but something interrupts—a phone call, a knock on the door, a look that suggests this isn't the resolution they expected. Maybe the quiet moment is there, but it's followed by something that changes its meaning. Consider ending with one character alone. Not necessarily because the relationship failed, but because that's where the story ends. Maybe Marlon stays at the cabin and Devon leaves; maybe they part ways with no dramatic conflict, just a quiet recognition that this was something that happened and now it's over. This would be a bold choice, and it might not be what readers want, but it would feel more honest than a conventional happy ending. Consider ending with an image that doesn't resolve. The plan ends with "two people together in the rain," which is beautiful but closed. What if it ended with something stranger—a detail that doesn't quite fit, a moment that resists interpretation, an image that leaves the reader with questions rather than closure? The best endings often do this; they make the story bigger than the plot by opening onto something that can't be contained. ### General Principles for Humanization Trust the reader to fill in gaps. Don't explain everything; let some things remain mysterious. Readers are smart, and they can handle ambiguity if the writing gives them enough to work with. Trust the characters to be contradictory. People aren't consistent, and neither should their fictional representations be. Let characters do things that don't fit their established patterns, make choices that confuse even them, reveal unexpected sides of themselves. Trust the process to produce unexpected results. An outline is a guide, not a contract. If the writing takes a turn that wasn't planned, follow it. The best stories often come from surprises—the writer discovering something they didn't know they were going to write. Embrace the rough edges. Writing that is always polished can feel like a mask. Sometimes a slightly awkward sentence, a slightly excessive metaphor, a slightly confused paragraph can carry more energy than smooth perfection. Write what scares you. If a scene feels too vulnerable, too dark, too ambiguous, that's probably the one that needs to be written. The LLM approach is to avoid the scary parts; the human approach is to lean into them. Remember that "human" doesn't mean "realistic." Fiction isn't reality, and it shouldn't try to be. But it should feel like it matters, like it came from somewhere inside the writer, like someone cared about getting it right. The goal isn't to imitate human imperfection but to generate writing that has the texture of genuine feeling—the imperfection is a byproduct, not a technique.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention **Core Premise and Emotional Purpose** This story is a queer neo-noir romance built around a single image: a man who is his own worst enemy, and the person who can't look away. The prompt "He was all cigarette smoke and bad ideas" becomes Marlon Mercer—not a redeemed criminal waiting for love to save him, but a man still in the process of destroying himself, who encounters someone (Devon) and finds, unexpectedly, that he wants to try something different. The romance isn't a cure; it's an experiment, a question posed to both characters: can we stop being the problem long enough to build something that might last? The answer isn't guaranteed, and the story doesn't pretend otherwise. **Character Intentions** Marlon is forty-three, Black, grew up in foster care, learned survival in criminal scenes that also gave him family when biological family failed. He has loved and lost and made choices he can't take back. The "cigarette smoke" isn't romantic—it's a physical fact of his life, something he knows is killing him but can't quit. The "bad ideas" aren't dashing eccentricity; they're patterns of self-sabotage, push-pull dynamics that have ruined relationships, a conviction that anyone who stays close will eventually leave or be hurt. His queerness is unremarkable to him; he's been with men and women and everyone in between when the chemistry was there. The crime isn't a lifestyle but a set of choices made by someone with few good options. Devon is thirty-four, Chinese-American, divorced, working at a small museum in Portland cataloging other people's art. His life has been careful to the point of numbness—he married someone appropriate, lived in appropriate neighborhoods, made appropriate choices. Coming out at thirty-two didn't unlock some hidden self; it just revealed that he'd been sleepwalking. He's drawn to Marlon not because Marlon is safe but because Marlon is the opposite, and Devon wants to feel something real even if it destroys him. His queerness is newer, still being negotiated. He's learning the spaces, the histories, the complicated dynamics of gay community, and he's not always graceful about it. The romance between them isn't destiny or salvation. It's two damaged people who recognize damage in each other and choose to reach across it anyway. The physical relationship is explicit because desire matters—it's not subtext but text, a force that complicates their partnership and makes them vulnerable in ways they hadn't planned. **Plot Intentions** The external plot is deliberately small: a single painting, not a masterpiece but a portrait done by a Black artist in the 1970s, stolen during the AIDS crisis as part of a punitive theft targeting the artist's estate. Marlon helped steal it thirty years ago and has lived with the weight of it since. He wants to return it—not to a museum but to the artist's surviving sister in Oakland, a woman who doesn't know the portrait exists. The painting is now in the collection of Harrison Voss, a wealthy collector who acquired it legally through a chain of custody that started with theft and exploitation. The heist isn't elaborate or glamorous. It requires inside help, careful timing, and luck. The stakes are real but not epic: prison if they're caught, but also the possibility that Marlon's attempt at redemption will fail and he'll have to live with the painting still out there. The story doesn't build toward a triumphant resolution; it builds toward a choice, a moment where both men decide what they're willing to risk and for whom. **Voice and Style** The prose is Devon's, filtered through close observation. Devon notices things because it's his job and his nature—he looks at surfaces and reads what others miss. But his observations aren't always right. He's learning to see Marlon, and he gets it wrong sometimes. The prose should feel like someone thinking, not someone performing thought. Sentences vary in length and complexity. Some passages are long and winding; some are short and sharp. The rhythm changes based on what's happening—tension speeds things up; quiet moments slow them down. The noir elements are present but earned. Rain, smoke, shadow—these appear when they make sense, not as atmosphere dressing. The setting is specific to Portland without becoming a travelogue: the particular quality of winter light, the neighborhoods where old money and new poverty sit side by side, the dive bars that have survived gentrification through stubbornness and low rents. The queer spaces are real places with histories, not aesthetic backdrops. **What I'm Aiming For** - Characters who are sympathetic but not saintly, damaged but not pitiable - A romance that develops through conflict and choice, not just chemistry - External stakes that matter without overwhelming the emotional core - Explicit, integral sensuality between the leads - An ending that offers hope without false certainty - Prose that varies in texture and rhythm, that feels like it's being written in time - A story that trusts the reader to fill gaps, to handle ambiguity, to care about imperfect people **What I'm Avoiding** - Redemption arcs that feel earned too easily - Antagonists who are purely villainous - Plots that resolve too neatly - Prose that performs its own cleverness - Queerness as either trauma or paradise - Safety in all its forms—emotional, moral, narrative --- # Chapter Planning **Chapter One: The Photograph** Devon is working late at the museum, photographing a new acquisition for the catalog. He's alone in the collection vault, doing tedious work that requires precision and rewards no one. He notices a small painting that doesn't match the acquisition records—unfinished, intimate, clearly a portrait of a Black man from the 1970s. Something about it feels off. That night, at The Anchor, a queer dive bar that has survived three decades of Portland's changes, Devon mentions the painting to Maxine, the bartender. Maxine tells him the painting belongs to someone else entirely. A man in the corner has been watching Devon all night. He approaches: "You're the one from the museum." His name is Marlon Mercer. He's all cigarette smoke and bad ideas. The chapter ends with Devon learning the painting's real history—and learning that he isn't the first person to notice it. *Word count focus: Establishing Devon through his eye for detail, his loneliness, his careful life. Introducing Marlon through Devon's observation—the way he moves, the way he speaks, the way he makes Devon feel seen. The Anchor as a specific place with specific history. The hook of the painting without over-explaining.* **Chapter Two: What's Missing** Marlon explains the painting's history over the course of a week—long conversations at The Anchor that stretch into early morning. He was twenty-three when he helped steal it, desperate for cash, following the lead of older men who offered belonging. The artist, James Thornton, died of AIDS in 1989; the theft was personal, punitive, targeting someone who had loved openly in a world that punished love. Marlon has lived with the weight of it for thirty years. Now he wants to return the painting to Thornton's sister, Iris, who lives in Oakland and doesn't know the portrait exists. The painting is in Harrison Voss's private collection; Voss acquired it legally through a chain of custody that began with theft. Devon should walk away. Instead, he finds himself agreeing to help. This chapter alternates between research (Devon pulling acquisition records, tracing provenance) and revelation (Marlon's past, his attempts at going straight, the relationships that didn't survive his choices). The attraction builds through friction: Devon doesn't trust his own judgment; Marlon doesn't trust anyone. The chapter ends with Devon finding a gap in Voss's security—and realizing he might be able to exploit it. *Word count focus: Building both characters through conversation and contrast. Establishing the external plot's parameters without becoming procedural. Marlon's history told in fragments, some more honest than others. Devon making a choice he can't explain.* **Chapter Three: The Shape of What's Coming** The planning phase. Devon and Marlon need inside help, and Marlon's network is smaller than it used to be. They reconnect with people who might assist: Jerome, a retired con artist who now teaches ceramics at a community college and has strong opinions about the ethics of theft; Marcus, Jerome's nephew, a young security guard at Voss's estate who needs money and asks few questions; Thalia and Ren, a couple who run a small firm that does digital security for artists and activists. These scenes introduce the broader world of small-time crime and the queer subculture that existed within it—men and women who found family in scenes that mainstream society rejected. Devon meets these people as Marlon's partner, not quite trusted but not dismissed. The romance intensifies through proximity—Devon staying late at Marlon's apartment, watching him sketch floor plans, arguing about whether stealing back something stolen is justice or just more theft. The chapter ends with a plan formed: Voss hosts a charity gala in two weeks; most of his security will be occupied. Devon, as a museum professional, has a plausible reason to be there as a guest. Marcus provides access to the private gallery. Marlon creates a distraction. The heist is simple, which makes Devon nervous. *Word count focus: World-building through character introduction without overwhelming exposition. The relationship developing through collaboration. The tension of waiting. The first hint that things might not go as planned.* **Chapter Four: The Burning** The first major romantic and emotional beat. Devon and Marlon have been circling each other for weeks, and the tension has become unbearable. During a stakeout in Marlon's car, watching Voss's estate, Devon leans over and kisses him. Marlon pulls away—not romantically, not gently, but with something like anger. "Everyone who gets close to me gets burned," he says. He tells Devon about the last person who loved him: Marcus's aunt, Denise, who took the fall for one of Marlon's cons and did three years in federal prison while he disappeared. He doesn't blame her for never speaking to him again. Devon pushes back, telling Marlon about his own damage—the safe marriage, the years of not seeing himself, the way he's spent his whole life choosing what won't hurt him and ending up numb. They fight. They kiss. They sleep together for the first time, rough and desperate and uncertain. Afterward, Marlon falls asleep smoking, and Devon watches him and thinks about what it means to want someone this badly. The chapter ends with Devon leaving before dawn, unsure what they've started. *Word count focus: The emotional confession, the physical intimacy, the vulnerability afterward. Marlon's history with real consequences. Devon confronting his own complicity in his numb life. The uncertainty of what comes next.* **Chapter Five: The Weight of It** Complications emerge. Voss's security company notices someone asking questions about the estate's layout; Marlon's face, familiar in certain circles, is identified from old photographs. A message arrives through intermediaries: return what you took or face consequences. At the same time, Devon's unexplained absences and questions about the collection have raised flags at the museum; he's put on administrative leave pending an investigation into his conduct. Marlon pushes Devon to step back—to let Marlon finish this alone, to protect what remains of Devon's careful life. Devon refuses, but the fight exposes how little they actually trust each other. Marlon's instinct is to sacrifice himself; Devon's instinct is to control. They separate, bitter and uncertain, for three days. Devon spends the time with Jules, an old friend who represents the life Devon could have had—stable, respected, expected. Jules sees Devon's distress and offers him a way out: a job in Seattle, a fresh start, an escape from whatever mess he's gotten into. The chapter ends with Devon in Jules's bright apartment, realizing he doesn't want that life anymore—but not knowing if Marlon wants him back. *Word count focus: External pressure mounting. The relationship at its breaking point. Jules as contrast and temptation. Devon's realization that safety isn't what he wants. The silence between him and Marlon.* **Chapter Six: What Holds** Marlon goes to Esther for advice; she tells him he's being a coward in the name of being noble. Devon returns to Marlon's apartment unannounced. They don't apologize—not in words—but they sit together in the dark, and Marlon puts out his cigarette, and they hold each other. The conversation that follows is halting, incomplete, more silence than speech. Marlon admits he doesn't know how to let someone stay. Devon admits he doesn't know how to stay for someone who's always leaving. They decide to continue with the heist—not because they've solved anything, but because they can't stop now. The chapter ends with a new plan: they need someone on the inside who isn't Marcus, someone Voss won't recognize. Marlon has an idea. It's risky. It's probably a bad idea. They do it anyway. *Word count focus: The reunion without easy resolution. The intimacy of imperfect honesty. The choice to continue despite uncertainty. The bad idea that might be their only option.* **Chapter Seven: Smoke and Mirrors** The heist itself. Voss's charity gala is underway; the estate is full of donors and art world people. Devon arrives as a guest, working the room, making small talk while keeping an eye on the private gallery. Marlon's distraction—a simulated emergency in another part of the estate—draws most of the security team away. But nothing goes exactly to plan. Marcus gets nervous when questioned by a supervisor and almost blows the whole operation. Devon finds the painting, but Voss has added new motion sensors since they last surveyed. He has to make a choice: take the painting and run, or stay and disable the alarm, risking everything. He stays. His hands shake. He disables the sensor with seconds to spare. The escape is messy—Marlon's car won't start at first, and they have to take a circuitous route to avoid patrol cars—but they make it to the meeting point with the painting in the back seat. Marlon looks at Devon like he's seeing him for the first time. They don't speak. They just drive. *Word count focus: Heist tension and pacing. The intimacy of the collaboration under pressure. Devon's choice to risk everything. The physical and emotional aftermath. Marlon's silence that says more than words.* **Chapter Eight: After the Rain** Resolution, of a kind. The painting is returned—not to a museum but to Iris Thornton in Oakland, who receives it with shock and grief and something like gratitude. Marlon makes the handoff in person; Devon waits in the car. Afterward, they drive to the coast, to a rented cabin where no one knows them. There's still fallout: Voss's people are looking for them, though the painting's provenance is now documented and Voss can't pursue it publicly. Devon's career at the museum is over, but he's applied to work with an arts nonprofit focused on returning stolen works to their communities. Marlon is still Marlon—smoke and bad ideas, the instinct to disappear when things get hard—but he's also here, choosing to stay, choosing to build something uncertain instead of burning it down. The ending is quiet: they sit on the cabin's porch, watching the rain, not talking about the future because the future is already here, uncertain and present and theirs to make or break. Marlon stubs out his last cigarette—for now, probably not forever—and takes Devon's hand. The story ends without resolution, just the two of them together in the rain, not knowing what comes next but facing it anyway. *Word count focus: Emotional resolution without tidy answers. The aftermath and what comes next. The intimacy of quiet choices. The final image of two people together in the rain, imperfect and uncertain and choosing each other anyway.*
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Devon Chen ## Background and Formation Devon Chen grew up in Beaverton, the suburban outskirts of Portland, in a second-generation Chinese-American household that operated on a philosophy of careful accumulation. His parents ran a small accounting firm out of their home—his mother's side of the business—and instilled in Devon and his older sister a belief that stability was the highest good. Risk was for other people. The Chen family did not get divorced. The Chen family did not have public failures. The Chen family kept its head down and accumulated quietly, and by the time Devon was in college, he had absorbed this philosophy so completely that he didn't recognize it as a philosophy anymore—it was simply how the world worked. He married Rachel in his late twenties because she was appropriate. She worked in nonprofit development, had a laugh that his parents approved of, came from a family that asked the right questions at the right times. The marriage was not unhappy, but it was not much of anything. They lived in a craftsman bungalow in Sellwood and hosted dinner parties where the conversation never got too deep. When Devon came out at thirty-two, two years after his mother died, Rachel was the one who helped him say it out loud. "I think you knew," she said, not unkindly. "I think I knew too. We just didn't want to say it." They divorced amicably, which is what you call a marriage that never had enough substance to be painful when it ended. The divorce was four years ago. Devon is thirty-four now, working as a registrar at a small contemporary museum called the Weller Collection, photographing acquisitions and maintaining provenance records. The work suits him—he's good at details, at tracking the invisible threads that connect objects to people. But the job has also become a kind of hiding place. He exists in the museum's climate-controlled quiet, surrounded by other people's art, cataloging things that matter more than he does. His exploration of queer life has been tentative, almost academic. He's read the theory, learned the history, navigated the apps with a mixture of eagerness and terror. But he hasn't yet found a place where he belongs. The Anchor, where he goes most nights after work, is the closest he's come—Maxine knows his drink (old fashioned, neat), and he can sit in the corner and watch the regulars without having to talk to anyone. It's a研究员's approach to community: observe first, participate later, if ever. ## Personality and Idiosyncrasies Devon's defining trait is his eye for detail—but it's also a limitation. He notices surfaces so vividly that he sometimes misses what's underneath. He's the kind of person who can describe a room perfectly but not quite recall how he felt in it. This makes him an excellent registrar and a frustrating romantic. He's been on dates where he could tell you exactly what the other person wore and how they held their coffee, but couldn't say whether he'd enjoyed himself. He's fastidiously organized in ways that border on ritualistic. His apartment is sparse, almost ascetic—a bookshelf with art monographs arranged by artist, a kitchen with exactly the number of utensils he needs. When he gets nervous, he alphabetizes. When he's upset, he cleans. His ex-wife once said that being with him felt like living inside a filing system, and the cruelty of the comment has stuck with him because it wasn't entirely wrong. Devon's social instincts are cautious to the point of self-sabotage. He defaults to the least risky option in any situation, then second-guesses the choice for weeks afterward. He has a pattern of almost-connections—people he almost befriended, conversations he almost had, moments he almost reached out. The "almost" is his defining preposition. His sense of humor is dry, observational, delivered with a flatness that sometimes makes people unsure whether he's joking. He doesn't laugh at his own jokes. He's not sure he finds most things funny. **Flaws:** Devon has a tendency to disappear from his own life. He watches himself from a slight distance, narrating his actions rather than inhabiting them. This makes him a good observer but a poor participant. He has also, in small ways, been cruel—most notably to Rachel, in the slow neglect of a marriage he knew wasn't working but couldn't bring himself to end. He's never fully acknowledged the ways he chose his own comfort over her honesty. He also has a habit of idealizing people from a distance, then being disappointed when they turn out to be human. **Specific idiosyncrasies:** - He cannot fall asleep without a specific podcast playing—a twenty-three-hour loop of a conservator discussing medieval manuscript restoration. He's listened to it so many times that he could recite it, but the rhythm of it still calms him. - He has a small scar on his left palm from a childhood accident involving a mandarin orange and his mother's antique ceramic bowl. He thinks about it more than is reasonable. - He takes photographs of the same tree in Laurelhurst Park, every month, for no reason he can articulate. He has hundreds of them on a hard drive. - He never orders the same drink twice at a new bar, but once he finds one that works, he sticks to it for years. The old fashioned at The Anchor is the first drink he's ordered consistently since he was twenty-three. ## Physicality Devon is average height, slightly built, with the kind of body that suggests he forgets to eat when he's absorbed in work. His face is angular, with deep-set eyes that give him a slightly scrutinizing expression even when he's not scrutinizing anything. His hair is black, kept shorter than it needs to be because he finds longer hair "unruly," a word he applied to himself without realizing it. He dresses in muted tones—gray, navy, olive—clothes that disappear into museum walls. He wears glasses he doesn't need except for reading, mostly because he likes the way they frame his face. When he's nervous, he touches his ear, a gesture so habitual he doesn't realize he's doing it. His movement is precise, economical. He doesn't fidget, doesn't make unnecessary gestures. He has the contained physicality of someone who's learned to take up minimal space, which makes his moments of absorption—when he forgets to be careful—stand out even more. He's the kind of person who will stand perfectly still in a gallery for twenty minutes, studying a painting, unaware that other people are working around him. When he speaks, he has a tendency to trail off at the end of sentences, as if he's already moving on to the next thought. His voice is softer than he intends; people often ask him to repeat himself. He's working on speaking more firmly, but it feels like acting. ## Motives, Allegiances, Relationships Devon's primary motive is to feel something real. He didn't come to this story looking for love; he came looking for a life. Marlon represents everything he's avoided—risk, damage, the willingness to be destroyed for the sake of being alive. Devon's attraction isn't healthy, but it's also not fake. He genuinely wants to know Marlon, and wanting has been so rare for him that he doesn't know what to do with it. His allegiances are fragmented. He has loyalty to his past (his parents' philosophy, his marriage, the careful life), to his present (his job, his apartment, his routines), and to the uncertain future he's starting to imagine with Marlon. He's not sure how to reconcile these loyalties, and the story will force him to choose. Existing relationships: - Rachel, his ex-wife. They still text occasionally, a formality that covers deeper resentment neither of them acknowledges. She doesn't know about Marlon. He hasn't told her much of anything about his post-divorce life. - Jules, an old friend from his museum studies program. Jules represents the career path Devon could have taken—ambitious, connected, successful. Jules's offer of a job in Seattle is genuine, but it's also a test, and Jules knows it. - Maxine, the bartender at The Anchor. Devon has been a regular for two years and still doesn't know her last name. This feels appropriate to him, almost comfortable. - His sister, Mei, who lives in Seattle and whom he sees twice a year. They're not close, but they're not estranged. They're just two people who share a language and a history and don't know what to do with either. ## Voice Experiments **Internal monologue:** "I should leave. This is the part where I leave, where I make the choice that makes sense, where I go home to my apartment and my podcast and my careful life. But the thing is—and I hate that I'm thinking this, because I know better—the thing is that I've been making that choice for thirty-four years, and it's gotten me a divorce and a job that feels like a hiding place and a thousand almost-conversations that I'm still having in my head at three in the morning. Marlon is looking at me like he knows exactly what I'm thinking, and I hate that too, because he's right. He's right and I'm tired of being right about my own smallness." **Dialogue:** Maxine: "You know he's trouble, right? Marlon Mercer. Whole city's got his number." Devon: "I noticed." Maxine: "And you're still here." Devon: "I'm taking notes." Maxine: "For what?" Devon: "I don't know yet. Something that isn't provenance records." --- # Marlon Mercer ## Background and Formation Marlon Mercer was born in Portland in 1981 and spent his first eighteen years moving between foster homes—twelve placements, three cities, a pattern of arriving and disappearing that left him without a sense of belonging to any place. He aged out of the system on his eighteenth birthday with a garbage bag of possessions and a high school diploma that meant less than it should have. No college savings. No family to fall back on. No idea how to be a person in a world that had never given him space to figure it out. He found belonging in other places: the bar scene on the east side, the house parties where everyone was queer or allied or didn't care; the network of small-time hustlers who moved merchandise that needed to disappear; the older men who saw something in him and taught him how to survive. It wasn't a healthy ecosystem, but it was an ecosystem. For the first time in his life, Marlon had people who would notice if he disappeared. He was twenty-three when he helped steal James Thornton's estate. He doesn't tell this part often, but when he does, he tells it straight: he needed the money, and the men who asked him were the closest thing he had to family, and he said yes before he thought about what it meant. The theft wasn't violent—no one was hurt—but it was cruel. Thornton had just died. The estate was in disarray. Marlon carried out paintings that Thornton had loved, and he sold them to dealers who asked no questions, and he used his share to pay six months of rent for the first time in his adult life. The guilt came later, and it never quite left. Marlon has spent thirty years in various forms of trying to make it right—small restitutions, connections with activists and artists, a persistent refusal to be the man he was in his twenties. He's been sober for three years, which feels like a longer time than it is. He still smokes, which he knows is killing him, but smoking is one of the few habits that hasn't been taken from him. His queerness is unremarkable to him. He was seventeen when he first kissed a boy at a house party, and it felt like the most natural thing in the world. He's been with women too, when the chemistry was there. He doesn't think about his sexuality as a defining characteristic, though he recognizes that the world does. His longest relationship was with a woman named Denise, a fellow hustler who eventually went to prison for a con that was mostly Marlon's idea. She hasn't spoken to him since she got out. He doesn't blame her. ## Personality and Idiosyncrasies Marlon is charming in a way that's almost involuntary—he's been reading rooms since childhood, learning to adapt to new placements, and the skill has become instinct. People trust him because he knows how to make them feel seen. This is also his most reliable tool for manipulation, and he's aware of the tension, even if he doesn't always resist it. He's funny, dry, quick with a comment that lands somewhere between insult and affection. He has a particular affection for older women—drag queens, bartenders, the women who run the community fridges and remember everyone's business. He says it's because they can't be charmed, which is true, but it's also because they remind him of the mothers he didn't have. His relationship with time is complicated. He lives in the present with an intensity that sometimes reads as presence and sometimes reads as denial. He doesn't think about the future because the future has never been reliable; he doesn't dwell on the past because the past is too heavy to carry. This makes him excellent in a crisis and terrible at maintenance. He can talk his way out of a police encounter but can't keep a plant alive. He has a pattern of self-sabotage that he recognizes but can't seem to stop. When things go well, he finds a way to undermine them. When someone gets close, he pushes them away—not cruelly, but with a kind of inevitability that feels like gravity. He's done this so many times that he no longer believes anything will be different. **Flaws:** Marlon is capable of genuine harm, and he's done it. He hurt Denise, and he hurt other people before her, and he carries that weight even though he doesn't always show it. He has a tendency to make himself the hero of his own story, to frame his self-destruction as tragic rather than chosen. He can be selfish in small, accumulating ways—taking without asking, assuming his needs will be accommodated, disappearing when things get difficult. He's not a bad person, but he's not a good one either. He's a person who has made choices that can't be undone and is trying to live with that. **Specific idiosyncrasies:** - He can sleep anywhere, any time—a survival skill from foster homes where quiet was never guaranteed. He can fall asleep in a chair during a conversation, wake up two hours later, and remember everything that was said. - He keeps a leather journal that he writes in obsessively, then hides in different places around his apartment. He's lost several over the years and never goes back to read them. The writing is for the act, not the artifact. - He has a small tattoo on his inner wrist—a stylized bird that he got at twenty and doesn't remember choosing. He's thought about covering it but never has. - He cannot drink coffee. It makes him shaky, anxious, unlike himself. He drinks tea instead, always with honey, always too hot. He burns his tongue on purpose sometimes, because the heat feels like something. ## Physicality Marlon is forty-three, with the kind of face that looks older in some lights and younger in others. He's tall, broad-shouldered, carrying weight that used to be muscle and is now something softer. He moves with a kind of deliberate ease, the physicality of someone who's learned not to telegraph his intentions. When he enters a room, he takes it in—exits, faces, potential threats—before he settles. His skin is dark brown, marked by a small scar above his left eyebrow from a childhood incident he doesn't remember. He wears his hair short, graying at the temples, cut practical and low-maintenance. His hands are his most expressive feature—always moving, gesturing, touching, cigarette cupped in palm like a prop he's performed with for years. He dresses in dark colors, layers, clothes that can be added or removed depending on the situation. He has a leather jacket he's owned for fifteen years, cracked and comfortable, that he wears even in summer when the heat is oppressive. He says it's a uniform; he doesn't mean it ironically. He smokes constantly—inside, outside, in his car, in bars that allow it. He's been told it's a nervous habit, but he's not sure what would replace it if he quit. The cigarette is a reason to pause, a reason to step outside, a reason to hold something while he thinks. Without it, he's not sure what he'd do with his hands. When he speaks, his voice is low and unhurried. He has a way of letting sentences trail off that makes people lean in, waiting for the rest. He's aware of this and does it less than he used to, but the habit persists. He laughs rarely, but when he does, it's genuine—a short, surprised sound, like he's forgotten he was capable of it. ## Motives, Allegiances, Relationships Marlon's primary motive is a kind of redemption he doesn't fully believe in. He wants to return the Thornton painting not because it will fix anything but because it's the only thing he can think to do. He wants to prove—to himself, if no one else—that he's more than the worst thing he ever did. Whether this is possible, he genuinely doesn't know. His allegiances are to the past (the people who made him, the scenes that shaped him) and to a present he's still figuring out. He's loyal to Esther, to Maxine, to the network of survivors who have made it this far. He's less loyal to himself, which is part of why his attempts at change keep failing. Existing relationships: - Denise, his ex, who won't speak to him. He sends her money sometimes, through intermediaries, and she takes it. He doesn't know what this means. - Esther, a drag queen who runs a community fridge and knows everyone's business. She's one of the few people who tells him hard truths and expects him to listen. - Jerome, a retired con artist who teaches ceramics. They go back twenty years, through scenes and schemes and one very bad year in Reno. Jerome doesn't trust him completely, but he shows up when it matters. - Marcus, Jerome's nephew, a young security guard who's desperate for money and doesn't ask many questions. Marlon cares about Marcus in the way he cares about everyone he can't quite save. - His biological sister, who he reconnected with once and then lost again. They have different fathers, different childhoods, no real connection beyond blood. He thinks about calling her and never does. ## Voice Experiments **Internal monologue:** "Devon's looking at me like I'm something. I know that look—I've seen it on faces for thirty years, in bars and back rooms and the backs of cars where transactions happened. The look that says please be what I need you to be. And I always was, that's the thing. I was always what people needed, because being useful was the only way to matter. Now he's looking at me like that, and I want to tell him: don't. I'm not what you need. I'm what you want, and wanting isn't the same thing. But I don't tell him. I never tell anyone. I just let them look, and hope they figure it out before they get burned." **Dialogue:** Devon: "Why did you come to me? Why this? Why now?" Marlon: "Because you're the one who noticed. That's not nothing." Devon: "Noticing isn't heroism." Marlon: "No. But it's where it starts. Someone has to see the thing before they can give it back. You saw it. So now we're here." Devon: "That's not an answer." Marlon: "It's the only one I have." --- # Secondary Characters (Brief) ## Maxine The bartender at The Anchor, in her late fifties, white, with the kind of face that's been through things and come out the other side sharper for it. She's seen Marlon at his worst and best and doesn't distinguish between them. She knows everyone's drink, everyone's secrets, and everyone's limits. She tells Devon things about Marlon without meaning to—small details, accumulated, that paint a picture of a man who's been trying to change for longer than he admits. **Voice sample:** "He used to come in here every night, three years ago, when he was still drinking. Never made a scene, never got loud. Just sat in the corner and drank until he couldn't sit anymore. Then one night he didn't show up for a month, and when he came back, he was different. Still bad ideas. Just... quieter about them." ## Esther A drag queen in her sixties, Black, who runs a community fridge out of her apartment building and functions as an informal social worker for the neighborhood's most vulnerable. She knew James Thornton, the artist, slightly—knew his work, knew his parties, knew the world he moved in. Her connection to Marlon is complicated; she doesn't approve of his past but recognizes a kindred survivor when she sees one. **Voice sample:** "Baby, everybody's got bad ideas. The question is whether you act on them. Marlon acted. That's the difference between him and the rest of us. He acted, and now he's got to live with it. Which he does. Mostly. When he remembers to." ## Harrison Voss The antagonist, in his sixties, white, wealthy beyond need, with a collection that includes work stolen during the AIDS crisis and work acquired through chains of custody that started with exploitation. He's not a cartoon villain—he genuinely believes he has a right to his collection, that his stewardship has preserved art that would otherwise have been lost. He's been collecting for forty years, and he's very good at protecting what he owns. **Voice sample:** "These pieces have provenance. I've spent decades documenting them. What happened before my ownership isn't my concern—it's history. Art survives through care, not through purity. And I've cared for these pieces better than anyone."

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter One: The Photograph The Weller Collection occupies a converted warehouse in the Pearl District, all exposed brick and climate-controlled cases, the kind of space that makes the art look more important by virtue of not looking like a museum at all. I work late on Wednesdays because the quiet is better then—no guards making rounds, no interns lost in the back offices, just me and the objects and the particular silence that lives inside buildings where no one is supposed to speak. My name is Devon Chen. I'm a registrar, which means I document. I photograph acquisitions, maintain provenance records, track the invisible threads that connect a painting to the person who made it and the person who owned it before that and the person who owned it before that. It's careful work. It's the kind of work that rewards someone who notices things. I was noticing things on a Wednesday in February when I found the photograph that didn't belong. The acquisition was a mixed lot—fifteen pieces from the estate of a deceased collector, mostly regional landscapes from the 1990s, the kind of work that goes for reasonable prices and hangs in dental offices and corporate lobbies. I'd photographed twelve of them already, the process mechanical by then: position, focus, capture, repeat. The thirteenth piece was different. It was small, maybe sixteen by twenty, an oil portrait unfinished in the way that suggests the artist died before they could finish. A Black man, middle-aged, dressed in a dark suit jacket over an unpainted background. His face was rendered with care—the kind of care that comes from knowing the subject—but his shoulders dissolved into raw canvas, and his left hand was barely sketched, a suggestion of fingers that never quite materialized. I noticed his eyes first. They were the kind of eyes that looked back. I should have moved on. The portrait wasn't remarkable enough to slow me down; it wasn't a masterpiece or a discovery or anything that would matter to the collection's directors. But I noticed something else: the style, the particular way the artist had built up the flesh tones, the signature in the lower right corner that I recognized without quite recognizing it. I photographed it anyway. Position, focus, capture. Then I pulled the acquisition records from my bag and started reading. The mixed lot was supposed to include fifteen pieces. Landscapes, all of them. The thirteenth piece was supposed to be a view of Mount Hood from the east, painted by a regional artist named Sandra Kish in 1994. The portrait in my hands was not a view of Mount Hood. The portrait in my hands was not even supposed to be here. I spent forty minutes checking the records, then rechecking them, then pulling the files for the other fourteen pieces to see if the portrait had been misfiled. It hadn't. The lot had come from the estate of a man named Gerald Weller—the same Weller the collection was named after—and the paperwork was immaculate, the kind of immaculate that suggests someone had been careful to make it look immaculate. I put the portrait back in its crate and finished my work. The remaining twelve pieces photographed without incident. I locked the vault and walked home through a light rain, the kind that doesn't quite qualify as precipitation but still manages to wet everything. --- The Anchor is a bar on a side street off Burnside, the kind of place that has survived three waves of Portland gentrification through stubbornness and low rents. The interior hasn't changed since the 1990s—dark wood, neon signs for beers that no longer exist, a jukebox that works but only plays selections from 1978. The crowd is mixed: older queers who remember when this was the only option, younger artists who found it through Instagram, a rotating cast of regulars who treat the bar like a living room. Maxine was behind the bar, wiping down a surface that didn't need wiping. She'd worked there for fifteen years, long enough to know everyone's drink without asking. Mine was an old fashioned, neat. She'd started making it before I sat down. "Rough day?" she asked. "Not rough. Weird." She waited. Maxine didn't push. That was one of the things I liked about her. "I found something at work," I said. "A painting that didn't match the acquisition records. Wrong piece, wrong provenance, probably wrong everything." "Someone steal something?" "I don't know. Maybe the estate was mixed up. Maybe someone made a mistake." I stirred my drink, the ice clicking against the glass. "Or maybe someone put something in there that wasn't supposed to be found." Maxine's expression didn't change, but something shifted behind her eyes. "What kind of painting?" "A portrait. Unfinished. Black man, 1970s, good artist, better than the rest of the lot. I recognized the signature but I can't place it." "You remember the name?" "Thornton. James Thornton." The name landed in the space between us, and I watched Maxine's face confirm something I hadn't known I was asking. She set down the rag she'd been using and leaned closer. "You said the portrait was here? At the museum?" "It's in the vault. Why?" Maxine glanced toward the corner of the bar, and I followed her gaze to a man I hadn't noticed before. He was sitting alone, a cigarette burning in an ashtray on his table, watching me with the kind of attention that felt like being read. Black, middle-aged, dressed in dark layers that suggested he'd been dressed for weather he wasn't currently experiencing. His hands were still, his posture relaxed, but his eyes were sharp. He looked like someone who had been waiting. "That's Marlon Mercer," Maxine said quietly. "He asked about you earlier. Said there was a photographer at the Weller who might know something about a painting." "I don't know anything." "You found something that isn't yours." It wasn't a question. "Maybe he can help you return it." The man—Marlon—stood up from his table and crossed the bar with the unhurried ease of someone who had learned not to rush. Up close, he looked older than I'd first thought, and more tired, and more alive. He had the kind of face that carried weight, the kind that suggested he'd been through things and was still standing.
